{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict=2007–08 Kenyan crisis |date=December 27, 2007 – February 28, 2008
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|month1=12|day1=27|year1=2007|month2=02|day2=28|year2=2008}}) |image= |caption=Clashes in [[Nairobi]] |place=[[Kenya]] |result=Creation of [[coalition government]] |casus=[[Kenyan presidential election, 2007|2007 Kenyan presidential election]] |combatant1= |combatant2= |commander1= |commander2= |strength1= |strength2= |casualties1= |casualties2= |casualties3=800–1,500 killed{{cite web|title=Kenya Ethnic Clashes Intensify |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/CA34AA32-041D-497D-BE2B-A463562C6FFF.htm |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=January 28, 2008 |accessdate=February 24, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220193929/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/CA34AA32-041D-497D-BE2B-A463562C6FFF.htm |archivedate=February 20, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|title=Report: Up to 1,000 killed in Kenyan crisis |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3491386,00.html |accessdate=February 24, 2008 |date=January 7, 2008 |publisher=[[Yedioth Ahronoth]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080309043428/http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0%2C7340%2CL-3491386%2C00.html |archivedate=March 9, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7344816.stm | title = Deal to end Kenyan crisis agreed | date = April 12, 2008 |publisher=BBC News | accessdate=April 12, 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080415082634/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7344816.stm| archivedate= April 15, 2008 | deadurl= no}}
180,000BBC World Service, programme World Have Your Say, Broadcast on World Service Fri Feb 29 – 18:06-600,000 displaced{{cite news | title = Kenya opposition cancels protests | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7344816.stm |publisher=BBC News | accessdate =December 9, 2014 | date = April 12, 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080110152443/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7344816.stm| archivedate=January 10, 2008 | deadurl= no}} }} The '''2007–08 Kenyan crisis''' was a political, economic, and humanitarian crisis that erupted in [[Kenya]] after former [[List of heads of state of Kenya|President]] [[Mwai Kibaki]] was declared the winner of the [[Kenyan presidential election, 2007|presidential election]] held on December 27, 2007. Supporters of Kibaki's opponent, [[Raila Odinga]] of the [[Orange Democratic Movement]], alleged [[electoral fraud|electoral manipulation]]. This was widely confirmed by international observers,{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7268903.stm |title=Kenya rivals agree to share power |publisher=BBC News |date=February 28, 2008 |accessdate=March 1, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080229154755/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7268903.stm| archivedate= February 29, 2008 | deadurl= no}} as being perpetrated by both parties in the election.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2008/09/18/uk-kenya-election-idUKLI38786120080918|title=Kenya's election seen as badly flawed|publisher=Reuters|date=September 18, 2008|accessdate=October 8, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141014134935/http://uk.reuters.com/article/2008/09/18/uk-kenya-election-idUKLI38786120080918|archivedate=October 14, 2014|df=mdy-all}} In part due to the ethnic and geographic diversity of Kenyan politics, no singular narrative can explain the reaction of opposition supporters to the announcement of Kibaki's swearing-in, which was done on December 30, 2007 in the evening. In addition to staging several non-violent protests, opposition supporters went on a violent rampage killing [[Kikuyu people|Kikuyus]]. [[Raila Odinga]] encouraged supporters to engage in mass protests which he announced on local television and radio stations, most noticeably in [[Mombasa]], [[Eldoret]], [[Kericho]], [[Kisumu]], [[Nakuru]] and parts of [[Nairobi]]. Police shot hundreds of violent demonstrators, including a few in front of TV news cameras, causing more violence.{{cite news |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DtFhwgyeVyI&feature=related |title=Police kill unarmed civilian |publisher=[[Kenya Television Network|KTN]] |date=January 16, 2008 |accessdate=July 11, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702132408/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DtFhwgyeVyI&feature=related |archivedate=July 2, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |author=(AFP) – Jan 26, 2008 |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jP2F5mh8PLTGOmbvw5hFR35VFGDg |title=AFP: Politician's portrait marks border in Kenyan slum |publisher=Google |date=January 26, 2008 |accessdate=May 1, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520174412/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jP2F5mh8PLTGOmbvw5hFR35VFGDg |archivedate=May 20, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} Targeted ethnic violence (as opposed to violent protests) escalated and at first was directed mainly against Kikuyu people—the community of which Kibaki is a member—living outside their traditional settlement areas, especially in the [[Rift Valley Province]].Samir Elhawary (2008) [http://www.odi.org.uk/resources/details.asp?id=1522&title=crisis-kenya-land-displacement Crisis in Kenya: land, displacement and the search for 'durable solutions'] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100226064907/http://www.odi.org.uk/resources/details.asp?id=1522&title=crisis-kenya-land-displacement |date=February 26, 2010 }} [[Overseas Development Institute]] The violence started with the murder of over 50 unarmed Kikuyu women and children, some as young as a month old, by locking them in a church and burning them alive in Kiambaa village near Eldoret, on [[New Year's Day]]. Tensions in the Rift Valley have caused violence in several previous Kenyan elections, most notably in the [[1992 Kenyan Elections]]. This prompted the Kikuyu to start defending themselves which forced the [[Luo people of Kenya and Tanzania|Luo]]s and [[Kalenjin people|Kalenjin]]s to stop the killings of the Kikuyus. In Mombasa, the Kenyan coastal residents took to the streets to protest the electoral manipulations and support their preferred candidate, Odinga. Tensions rose as the landless indigenous Coastal communities felt this was a time to avenge the grabbing of their land by mainly up–country Kikuyu. Looters also struck a number of stores in Mombasa. The slums of Nairobi saw some of the worst violence, some of it ethnically motivated, some expression of outrage at extreme poverty, and some the actions of criminal gangs. The violence continued sporadically for several months, particularly in the Rift Valley. Former [[UN Secretary General]] [[Kofi Annan]] arrived in the country about a month after the election and successfully brought the two sides to the negotiating table. On February 28, 2008, Kibaki and Odinga signed a power-sharing agreement called the [[National Accord and Reconciliation Act 2008]], which established the office of the Prime Minister and created a [[coalition government]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7269476.stm |title=Key points: Kenya power-sharing deal |publisher=BBC News |date=February 28, 2008 |accessdate=March 1, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080303050904/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7269476.stm| archivedate= March 3, 2008 | deadurl= no}} The power-sharing Cabinet, headed by Odinga as Prime Minister, was eventually named on April 13, after lengthy negotiations over its composition;[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/2D1674A2-3AF1-47C8-B687-A7D530EC8BD2.htm "Kenya unveils 40-seat cabinet"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080614151908/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/2D1674A2-3AF1-47C8-B687-A7D530EC8BD2.htm |date=June 14, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, April 13, 2008. it was sworn in on April 17.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E991FAE0-2FD8-4B72-AFE7-0C2B1F9E89FC.htm "Odinga sworn in as Kenya PM"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080526092152/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E991FAE0-2FD8-4B72-AFE7-0C2B1F9E89FC.htm |date=May 26, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, April 17, 2008. ==Background== {{Main|Kenyan presidential election, 2007}} [[File:Raila and the media.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Orange Democratic Movement]] leader [[Raila Odinga]] speaks with Kenyan media]] The post-election demonstration and violence stemmed from a mixture of motives. Some included: *Voting in elections has widely been along ethnic lines in many Kenyan communities{{cite web|last=Bernardi|first=Nikita|title=Kenya's Coalitions of Convenience and Ethnic Politicking|url=http://thinkafricapress.com/kenya/coalitions-convenience-and-ethnic-politicking-tana-delta|work=Think Africa Press|accessdate=11 December 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121215143514/http://thinkafricapress.com/kenya/coalitions-convenience-and-ethnic-politicking-tana-delta|archivedate=December 15, 2012|df=mdy-all}} *Widespread perception that the count of the presidential election was modified in favour of Kibaki *During colonial times Kikuyu people were displaced from their fertile highlands and after independence they were settled outside their traditional areas especially in the Rift Valley, where the ethnic [[Maasai people]] had populated originally before Kenya's colonization by the [[British Empire|British]].{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7213211.stm | work=BBC News | title=Kenya's geographic and political rift | date=January 28, 2008 | accessdate=April 22, 2010 | first=Mark | last=Doyle | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090929215008/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7213211.stm | archivedate=September 29, 2009 | df=mdy-all }} *A belief among other tribes that the Kikuyu community in Kenya has dominated the country since independence[http://www.kenyaredcross.org/UserFiles/File/Kenya_Ethnic_Clashes-Info_Bulletin_No.4-25.7.07.pdf "Information Bulletin; Kenya: Ethnic Clashes"], Kenyan Red Cross Society, July 25, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080216043727/http://www.kenyaredcross.org/UserFiles/File/Kenya_Ethnic_Clashes-Info_Bulletin_No.4-25.7.07.pdf |date=February 16, 2008 }} Reports by international observers about manipulations and admissions by members of the [[Electoral Commission of Kenya]] that their staff provided them with incorrect figures have further fuelled this anger.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7165602.stm |title=Scores Dead in Kenya Poll Clashes |publisher=BBC |date=December 31, 2007 |accessdate=December 31, 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080101153836/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7165602.stm| archivedate= January 1, 2008 | deadurl= no}} The violence has been directed mainly against [[Kikuyu people|Kikuyus]], belonging to the same ethnic group as Kibaki.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/31/world/africa/31kenya.html |work=The New York Times |first=Jeffrey |last=Gettleman |title=Disputed Vote Plunges Kenya Into Bloodshed |date=December 31, 2007 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110325070737/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/31/world/africa/31kenya.html |archivedate=March 25, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} The violence against Kikuyus occurred all over the country but was higher in areas like the Nairobi slums, [[Nyanza Province]], the [[Rift Valley Province, Kenya|Rift Valley]], and the Coast, where opposition against Kibaki is particularly strong.{{cite news | title = Scores dead in Kenya poll clashes | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7165602.stm#map | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | work = BBC News | date = December 31, 2007 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080101153836/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7165602.stm#map | archivedate = January 1, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} The ethnically diverse Nairobi slums have also seen violence by Kikuyu-dominated groups—amongst them the infamous [[Mungiki]]—against neighbours hailing from western parts of Kenya.[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=104196 "Kenya poll violence deaths hit 300"]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=The Rambling Man |fix-attempted=yes }}, Reuters (abs-cbnnews.com), January 2, 2008. ==Timeline== [[File:Kenya Provinces 2007 elections.PNG|thumb|Map of Kenya, indicating majority per province for the two leading presidential candidates according to disputed official figures. Please note that the area size on the map does not indicate population density: the provinces to the East and North East are generally low population density provinces.]] A [[BBC]] reporter saw 40 bodies with gunshot wounds in a mortuary in [[Kisumu]], which was the opposition's main base. A witness also told them that armed police shot protesters at a rally. There were running battles in the [[Nairobi]] slums. The local KTN television station said that 124 people died nationwide in the first two days of unrest.{{cite news |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200712310456.html |title=Kenya: Death and Chaos After Kibaki Win |publisher=The Nation (Nairobi) |date=December 31, 2007 |accessdate=December 31, 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080103085403/http://allafrica.com/stories/200712310456.html| archivedate= January 3, 2008 | deadurl= yes}} On December 31, 2007, police reported that 40 people were killed in Nairobi and 53 in Kisumu, a major support base for Odinga. Four bodies were discovered in [[Mathare]], in Nairobi, seven people were killed in [[Nakuru]], and four people found dead in a village near [[Kapsabet]].[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E952236D-EA1E-47D0-9BB6-0012EC14AAC8.htm "Election riots worsen in Kenya"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103075747/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E952236D-EA1E-47D0-9BB6-0012EC14AAC8.htm |date=January 3, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, December 31, 2007. ===Disputed results=== Early results tallied indicated that Odinga held a strong lead on December 28, the day after the election, and the ODM declared victory for Odinga on December 29;[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=nw20071229123805553C415151 "Kenya opposition declares victory"], AFP (''IOL''), December 29, 2007. {{dead link|date=September 2011}} however, as more results were announced on the same day, the gap between the two candidates narrowed, and with almost 90% of the votes counted (180 out of 210 constituencies), Odinga's lead shrank to only 38,000 votes.[http://www.sabcnews.com/africa/east_africa/0,2172,161636,00.html "Kenya election results expected today"], SABC News, December 30, 2007. {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120910082727/http://www.sabcnews.com/africa/east_africa/0,2172,161636,00.html |date=September 10, 2012 }} At a press conference on the morning of December 30, Odinga accused the government of fraud, urged Kibaki to concede defeat, and called for a recount. He said that the ODM would not take the matter to the courts claiming that the courts were controlled by Kibaki.Stephen Ndegwa, [http://allafrica.com/stories/200712300020.html "Kenya: Raila Calls for Vote Recount"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102104956/http://allafrica.com/stories/200712300020.html |date=January 2, 2008 }}, ''The East African Standard'' (allAfrica.com), December 30, 2007. The Electoral Commission declared Kibaki the winner on December 30, placing him ahead of Odinga by about 232,000 votes.Barney Jopson, [http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto010320080354570443&page=2 "Kenyan police try to block opposition rally"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711050040/http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto010320080354570443&page=2 |date=July 11, 2011 }}, Reuters (''Financial Times''), January 3, 2008.{{cite news | url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/world/kenyans-riot-after-rigged-election/2007/12/31/1198949705836.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 | location=Melbourne Australia | work=The Age | title=Kenyans riot after 'rigged' election | date=December 31, 2007 | accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090918053638/http://www.theage.com.au/news/world/kenyans-riot-after-rigged-election/2007/12/31/1198949705836.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 | archivedate=September 18, 2009 | df=mdy-all }}{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7164890.stm| work=BBC News| title=Kibaki named victor in Kenya vote| date=December 30, 2007| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604041747/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7164890.stm| archivedate=June 4, 2016| df=mdy-all}} According to Odinga, as many as 300,000 votes for Kibaki were falsely included in his total. The Chairman of the Electoral Commission, Samuel Kivuitu, said that while irregularities affecting the entire exercise did occur, they were a matter for the courts, not the Electoral Commission.Jeffrey Gettleman, [http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/12/30/africa/kenya.php "Tribal violence breaks out in Kenya over disputed election result"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119232122/http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/12/30/africa/kenya.php |date=January 19, 2008 }}, ''International Herald Tribune'', December 30, 2007. Supporters of Kibaki, meanwhile, said that discrepancies had actually worked in Odinga's favor, arguing that discrepancies between polling station tallies and Electoral Commission results meant that Odinga had gained 53,000 votes while Kibaki had lost 106,000. Following the Commission's declaration of his victory, Kibaki was promptly sworn in for his second term late in the evening on the same day,{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/12/30/AR2007123002506_pf.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Stephanie | last=McCrummen | title=Incumbent Declared Winner in Kenya's Disputed Election | accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030085559/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/12/30/AR2007123002506_pf.html | archivedate=October 30, 2012 | df=mdy-all }} calling for the "verdict of the people" to be respected and for "healing and reconciliation" to begin. Kivuitu said that there were some problems in the vote counting, noting that in one constituency the reported turnout rate was 115%.{{cite news|title=Violence follows re-election of Kenya's president|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/2007-12-30-kenya_N.htm?csp=34|accessdate=11 December 2012|newspaper=USA Today|date=30 December 2007}} According to the [[European Union]]'s head observer in the election, Alexander Graf Lambsdorff, the election was "flawed" and the Electoral Commission failed to establish "the credibility of the tallying process to the satisfaction of all parties and candidates";[http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto123020071125520138&page=2 "Kibaki re-elected as president of Kenya"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711050027/http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto123020071125520138&page=2 |date=July 11, 2011 }}, Reuters (''Financial Times''), December 30, 2008. he said that in some places EU observers were not allowed to see vote tallies until the Electoral Commission announced them: "the whole point...is to verify that the results are the same". The United Kingdom's Foreign Secretary, [[David Miliband]], said that his country had "real concerns" about the election. While the United States initially congratulated Kibaki and called for the results to be respected,{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7165406.stm| work=BBC News| title=Odinga rejects Kenya poll result| date=December 31, 2007| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103050537/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7165406.stm| archivedate=January 3, 2008| df=mdy-all}} it also expressed concern,{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/12/31/wkenya431.xml |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |first=Mike |last=Pflanz |title=Kenya election riots leave more than 120 dead |date=December 31, 2007 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080404155607/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2007%2F12%2F31%2Fwkenya431.xml |archivedate=April 4, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} and on January 2, 2008 a spokesman for the [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] declined to confirm U.S. recognition of Kibaki's victory.David Gollust, [http://www.voanews.com/english/2008-01-02-voa73.cfm "US in Diplomatic Push to End Kenya Violence"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080106105922/http://www.voanews.com/english/2008-01-02-voa73.cfm |date=January 6, 2008 }}, VOA News, January 2, 2007.In a telex from then US Embassy in Nairobi to the State Department in Washington DC [released in July 2012], US Ambassador Michael Ranneberger set out five scenarios as to who really won the election. He wrote, ‘In all cases the margin of victory for either side is slim and ultimately unknowable’. The telex also noted that there was ‘evidence of rigging on both sides’{{cite web|title=FOIA Release DOC NO C17443900 JANUARY 2008|url=http://www.kenyadocex.com/wiki/foia-release-doc-no-c17443900-january-2008/|website=Kenyadocex.com|accessdate=13 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170813223126/http://www.kenyadocex.com/wiki/foia-release-doc-no-c17443900-january-2008/|archivedate=August 13, 2017|df=mdy-all}}and {{cite web|title=US Embassy: Was the election stolen?|url=http://www.kenyaforum.net/2017/08/07/us-embassy-was-the-election-stolen/|accessdate=13 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170813183246/http://www.kenyaforum.net/2017/08/07/us-embassy-was-the-election-stolen/|archivedate=August 13, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Kivuitu said on January 2, that he had been pressured by PNU and ODM-K (Kibaki's and [[Kalonzo Musyoka]]'s parties) into announcing the results without delay, and he claimed that he did not personally know who really won.{{cite web|url=http://www.eastandard.net/news/?id=1143979833 |title=The Standard | Online Edition | I acted under a pressure, says Kivuitu |publisher=Eastandard.net |date=July 4, 2007 |accessdate=May 1, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090216114038/http://eastandard.net/news/?id=1143979833| archivedate=February 16, 2009| deadurl= yes}} Within minutes of the Commission's declaration of Kibaki as victor, tribe-based rioting and violence, primarily directed against Kikuyus, broke out across Kenya, and the government suspended live television coverage for some days.The Nation, [http://allafrica.com/stories/200712310011.html "Kenya: Violence Erupts After Kibaki Sworn in"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080215110057/http://allafrica.com/stories/200712310011.html |date=February 15, 2008 }}, The Nation (allafrica.com), December 30, 2007.The Nation, [http://allafrica.com/stories/200712310456.html "Kenya: Death and Chaos After Kibaki Win"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103085403/http://allafrica.com/stories/200712310456.html |date=January 3, 2008 }}, The Nation (allafrica.com), December 31, 2007. Odinga alleged that "a clique of people around Kibaki" sought to rig the election, but said that democracy "is unstoppable like the flow of the Nile". The ODM announced its intention to hold a ceremony on December 31, in which Odinga would be declared the "people's president", but police said that this could incite violence and that Odinga could be arrested if the ceremony occurred. Odinga then delayed this, but called for a million-strong rally on January 3, 2008{{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/12/31/world/main3658021.shtml?source=search_story | work=CBS News | title=Violence Grips Kenya After Contested Vote | date=December 31, 2007 | accessdate=May 10, 2008 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524125333/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/12/31/world/main3658021.shtml?source=search_story | archivedate=May 24, 2011 | df=mdy-all }} and for his supporters to wear black armbands as a show of mourning.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1699123,00.html |work=Time |title=Will Kenya's Vote Lead to Tribal War? |date=December 31, 2007 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421151355/http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0%2C8599%2C1699123%2C00.html |archivedate=April 21, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Odinga said that the ODM would not negotiate with Kibaki unless he resigned, because to do so would, according to Odinga, mean acknowledging Kibaki's legitimacy; he also said that, unless stopped, the "ruling clique" could rig the next election in five years as well, and that he was not afraid of being arrested, having been jailed many times in the past.[http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=2&newsid=113719 "Raila’s terms for talks with Kibaki on crisis"], ''Daily Nation'' (Kenya), January 1, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080222061055/http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=2&newsid=113719 |date=February 22, 2008 }} For his part, Kibaki emphasized the importance of peace, stability, and tolerance in his 2008 New Year's message, speaking of the election as a concluded event and warning that law-breakers would be punished.Fred Mukinda and Samwel Kumba, [http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=2&newsid=113722 "Kibaki warns law breakers of stern action"], ''Daily Nation'' (Kenya), January 1, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080222062752/http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=2&newsid=113722 |date=February 22, 2008 }} ===Rallies=== [[File:ODM - Raila Odina portrait.jpg|thumb|right|[[Orange Democratic Movement]] supporters at a rally during the 2007–08 Kenyan crisis]] Odinga said that the million-strong rally in his support planned for January 3 would take place in spite of a government ban, and he accused the government of being directly responsible for "genocide". Electoral Commission Chairman Kivuitu said on January 1, that he had been pressured by the PNU and ODM-Kenya to announce results immediately, despite the urgings of Western ambassadors to delay the results so that concerns about irregularities could be addressed.{{cite news | url=http://news.smh.com.au/up-to-50-people-killed-in-kenya-church/20080102-1jt7.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | first=Elizabeth | last=Kennedy | title=Up to 50 people killed in Kenya church | date=January 2, 2008 | accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080303014425/http://news.smh.com.au/up-to-50-people-killed-in-kenya-church/20080102-1jt7.html | archivedate=March 3, 2008 | df=mdy-all }} On January 3, opposition supporters attempted to gather for the planned rally in [[Uhuru Park]], but police fought them off with tear gas and water cannons. Another attempt to hold the rally was planned for January 4. Also on January 3, Kibaki said that he was willing to engage in dialogue "once the country is calm", and he described the continuing violence as "senseless", while Attorney General [[Amos Wako]] called for a recount, an investigation into the election, and the formation of a national unity government, saying that the situation was "quickly degenerating into a catastrophe of unimaginable proportions".{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/01/03/kenya.violence/ |publisher=CNN |title=Opposition plans rally in Nairobi |date=January 4, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080225101040/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/01/03/kenya.violence/ |archivedate=February 25, 2008 |df=mdy }} Finance Minister [[Amos Kimunya]] said that if the ODM did not allege fraud, that would make it easier for the two sides to talk; Kimunya also said that the government wanted to mediate through Kenyan elders and did not want international mediation involving the African Union. KANU's [[Uhuru Kenyatta]] said that it might be possible for the two sides to work together, but that the ODM's position that Kibaki should resign before any talks took place was unacceptable, because then there would be "no government". On January 4, ODM Secretary-General [[Anyang Nyongo]] called for a new presidential election to be held,[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080104.wkenyanew0104/BNStory/International/?page=rss&id=RTGAM.20080104.wkenyanew0104 "Kenya opposition demands new vote"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105171947/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080104.wkenyanew0104/BNStory/International/?page=rss&id=RTGAM.20080104.wkenyanew0104 |date=January 5, 2008 }}, Associated Press (''Globe and Mail'', Canada), January 4, 2008.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7171552.stm| work=BBC News| title=Kenya opposition wants new polls| date=January 4, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107134023/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7171552.stm| archivedate=January 7, 2008| df=mdy-all}} without the involvement of the Electoral Commission. Government spokesman Alfred Mutua said that this would be possible only if it was decided by the courts. After meeting U.S. Assistant Secretary of State [[Jendayi Frazer]], Kibaki said on January 5, that he was willing to form a national unity government, but Odinga, who also met with Frazer, rejected this, saying that Kibaki "should not come to the negotiating table as the president" and calling for the creation of a transitional government leading to a new election in three to six months.C Bryson Hull and Barry Moody, [http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=nw20080105145905250C451693 "Opposition brushes aside Kibaki offer"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080106233628/http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=nw20080105145905250C451693 |date=January 6, 2008 }}, Reuters (''IOL''), January 5, 2008. However, after Odinga met with Frazer for a second time shortly afterward, Odinga's spokesman said that the ODM would not demand that Kibaki resign or admit defeat if he accepted an international mediator. At about the same time, while violence continued, it was reported to be decreasing in Nairobi.{{cite news | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/01/06/MN45UA484.DTL&type=politics | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | first=Ron | last=Dixon | title=Across country, Kenya's tribes segregate themselves / President hints unity government might be possible | date=October 10, 2010 | accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525135218/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2008%2F01%2F06%2FMN45UA484.DTL&type=politics | archivedate=May 25, 2011 | df=mdy-all }} ===Kufuor mediation=== On January 6, Odinga called for rallies to be held on January 8, despite the government's insistence that the rallies would be illegal. Odinga's spokesman said that while the ODM ruled out a government of national unity, it could discuss "a coalition government with genuine power sharing" (which it said would leave less power for Kibaki than would be the case in a national unity government) or establishing an interim government to hold a new election.[http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/01/06/africa/AF-GEN-Kenya-Election-Violence.php "Kenyan opposition leader willing to discuss power sharing, calls mass rallies"], Associated Press (''International Herald Tribune''), January 6, 2008. Odinga subsequently cancelled the rallies planned for January 8,{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7174670.stm| work=BBC News| title=Kenya opposition cancels protests| date=January 7, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110152443/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7174670.stm| archivedate=January 10, 2008| df=mdy-all}}Lucas Barasa and Rachel Ombaka, [http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=1&newsid=114181 "End of turmoil in sight as AU boss jets in"], ''Daily Nation'', January 8, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080120214327/http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=1&newsid=114181 |date=January 20, 2008 }} saying that the mediation process, facilitated by Ghanaian President and African Union Chairman [[John Kufuor]], was about to begin, with Kibaki having officially invited Kufuor, and that negotiations needed to take place in a peaceful atmosphere. Odinga said that he anticipated direct talks involving both himself and Kibaki, with Kufuor's participation. Foreign Minister [[Raphael Tuju]] said that by calling off the rallies, Odinga opened the way for negotiation and reconciliation.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E458D123-7FEA-420D-8E78-545DC4E37D85.htm "Kenya leaders agree to talk"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108195015/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E458D123-7FEA-420D-8E78-545DC4E37D85.htm |date=January 8, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, January 7, 2008. There exist doubts that Kibaki really invited Kufuor (as opposed to him having come as a result of international concern for the worsening situation in Kenya).{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} PNU members of parliament, newly appointed cabinet ministers and even the government spokesman, Dr Alfred Mutua, are known to have said Kufuor "was coming to take tea", and not to "negotiate with the warring factions regarding the elections"; this was captured both on TV and print media. In addition, the PNU side was actively downplaying the seriousness of the post-election crisis, saying that this was a local problem that would be dealt with locally. It even urged the displaced people at various police stations and camps to 'return home' and generally tried to dissuade international attention to the crisis. It is also worth noting that there were conflicting reports from Ghanaian weblogs about President Kufuor's visit. Some weblogs said he was not going to travel to Kenya, since the government did not view him as a welcome visitor, others saying he was required by his official responsibility as AU chairman to try to resolve the crisis in Kenya. Just before Kufuor's travel to Kenya, Moses Wetang'ula, the new Minister for Foreign Affairs travelled to Ghana to 'brief Mr. Kufuor' on the situation in Kenya, ahead of his trip to Kenya. These actions were perceived to be an indication of bad faith on the part of Kibaki and his team, and they preempted their bias against the talks between President Kibaki (and his PNU side) and Raila (and his ODM side). There were also indications that PNU did not want the discussion to be mediated by an outsider.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} Odinga refused to accept Kibaki's offer to hold talks unless they took place as part of international mediation, saying that without having Kufuor present to mediate the talks would be a "sideshow" and a "public relations gimmick", and he claimed that Kibaki was using the offer of talks between himself and Odinga to divert attention from Kufuor.Nicolo Gnecchi, [http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Kenya_s_Odinga_rejects_bilateral_talks_with_government.html?siteSect=143&sid=8602773&cKey=1199802269000&ty=ti "Kenya's Odinga rejects bilateral talks with government"], Reuters (swissinfo), January 8, 2008. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Meanwhile, Frazer said on January 7, that there had been rigging in the election, but she said that both sides could have engaged in rigging. She also previously said that Kenyans had "been cheated by their political leadership and their institutions".{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/07/ap/world/main3681998.shtml |work=CBS News |title=Kenyans cheated by their political leadership }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Kibaki appointed 17 ministers as part of a new Cabinet on January 8, saying that the rest of the Cabinet would be appointed later. The Cabinet included the ODM-K's [[Kalonzo Musyoka]] as Vice-President and Minister of Home Affairs and KANU's Uhuru Kenyatta as Minister of Local Government.[http://allafrica.com/stories/200801080673.html "Kenya: Kibaki Names Cabinet"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001163336/http://allafrica.com/stories/200801080673.html |date=October 1, 2012 }}, ''The East African Standard'' (allAfrica.com), January 8, 2008.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7177338.stm| work=BBC News| title=Kenya leader names new ministers| date=January 8, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080112092716/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7177338.stm| archivedate=January 12, 2008| df=mdy-all}} Announcing these appointments, Kibaki said: "I have considered the importance of keeping the country united, peaceful and prosperous and a strong broad-based leadership." The ODM's Nyongo said that this Cabinet, in which the ODM was not included, was illegitimate because Kibaki did not win the election. Renewed outbreaks of violence were reported following Kibaki's announcement. With almost half of the Cabinet yet to be named, it was suggested that Kibaki intended to leave the remaining ministries open so that they would be available for the ODM following the negotiations; however, it was also noted that the most important ministries were already filled. [[Musalia Mudavadi]], a leading figure in the ODM, denounced Kibaki's announcement as being intended only to sabotage mediation with Kufuor.[http://www.eastandard.net/news/?id=1143980146&cid=4 "Kalonzo VP in Kibaki’s new Cabinet"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213023516/http://www.eastandard.net/news/?id=1143980146&cid=4 |date=February 13, 2008 }}, ''The Standard'' (Kenya), January 9, 2008. The ''Daily Nation'' said that Kibaki's move would "be seen as a sign of bad faith" and that it could "poison the atmosphere". U.S. State Department spokesman [[Sean McCormack]] said that it appeared Kibaki was setting up a ''fait accompli'', that the U.S. was "disappointed" by the move, and that it had "expressed its displeasure".Wangui Kanina and Duncan Miriri, [http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/African_Union_head_meets_Kenya_s_feuding_parties.html?siteSect=143&sid=8599190&cKey=1199912982000&ty=ti "African Union head meets Kenya's feuding parties"], Reuters (swissinfo), January 9, 2008. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} ===Annan mediation=== On January 9, Kufuor met separately with Kibaki and Odinga. Government statements on that day emphasized Kibaki's commitment to dialogue and said that he had "already initiated a process of dialogue with other Kenyan leaders". Kibaki also gave a speech in which he said that the vote was concluded, that it was impossible to change the outcome, and that any complaints should be handled through the courts.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/10/world/main3695650.shtml | work=CBS News | title=Kofi Annan Takes Over Kenya Mediation | date=January 10, 2008 | accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080116184756/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/10/world/main3695650.shtml | archivedate=January 16, 2008 | df=mdy-all }} The two sides agreed to "an immediate cessation of violence as well as any acts which may be detrimental to finding a peaceful solution to the ongoing crisis", but the talks otherwise failed when, according to Nyongo, Kibaki refused to sign an agreement (which was already signed by ODM representatives) presented to him by Kufuor[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/2F5BFC9A-18D3-4816-8C49-BD7114B93083.htm "Kenya mediation talks fail"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312200715/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/2F5BFC9A-18D3-4816-8C49-BD7114B93083.htm |date=March 12, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, January 10, 2008. that would have provided for an interim coalition government and an inquiry into the Electoral Commission; the government, however, blamed Odinga for the failure of the talks, saying that he was not responsive to Kibaki's offer of dialogue.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/F68ED2CD-24A3-4DBE-B636-FB7503F91415.htm "Kenya police ban new mass protests"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080215235933/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/F68ED2CD-24A3-4DBE-B636-FB7503F91415.htm |date=February 15, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, January 11, 2008. Kufuor left Kenya on January 10, saying that both parties had agreed to continue talks together with former United Nations Secretary-General [[Kofi Annan]] and "a panel of eminent African personalities"; Annan's office subsequently said that he would lead future talks but that he was not likely to go to Kenya before January 15,. Kibaki's new Cabinet ministers were sworn in on January 10,. On January 11, the ODM called for mass rallies to be held in about 30 places in the following week; the police said that the rallies were banned. Nyongo also called for international sanctions against Kibaki's government. On January 12, the EU said that there could not be "business as usual in Kenya" without a compromise and a solution to the dispute,{{cite news | url=http://news.smh.com.au/pressure-mounts-on-kenyas-leaders/20080113-1lnb.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | first1=Daniel | last1=Wallis | first2=Alistair | last2=Thomson | title=Pressure mounts on Kenya's leaders | date=January 13, 2008 | accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314042916/http://news.smh.com.au/pressure-mounts-on-kenyas-leaders/20080113-1lnb.html | archivedate=March 14, 2008 | df=mdy-all }} and Frazer also said that the US could not conduct "business as usual in Kenya" under the circumstances, saying that Kibaki and Odinga should meet in person, "without preconditions", and that both sides "should acknowledge serious irregularities in the vote tallying which made it impossible to determine with certainty the final result". In addition, she called for the lifting of the bans on live television coverage and rallies.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/13/world/africa/13kenya.html |work=The New York Times |first=Jeffrey |last=Gettleman |title=U.S. Presses Kenyan President and Opposition Leaders to Meet |date=January 13, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516175129/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/13/world/africa/13kenya.html |archivedate=May 16, 2013 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Roads and Public Works Minister [[John Michuki]] said on January 14, that Annan was not coming at the government's invitation and reiterated the claim that Kibaki won the election. EU Development Commissioner [[Louis Michel]] said on the same day that EU aid to Kenya could be reduced as a result of the election. Parliament opened on January 15, and Annan was expected to arrive on the same day. ODM Members of Parliament said that they intended to sit on the government side in Parliament, asserting their claim to have won the election.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7188524.stm| work=BBC News| title=Angry exchanges as Kenya MPs meet| date=January 15, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118152826/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7188524.stm| archivedate=January 18, 2008| df=mdy-all}} They took the opposition side, however, with Odinga taking the Leader of the Opposition's seat. Although the ODM wanted an open ballot instead of a secret one in the election for the [[Speaker of the Parliament of Kenya|Speaker of Parliament]], the government side opposed this and the vote was conducted through secret ballot. In the first round of voting, the ODM's candidate for Speaker, [[Kenneth Marende]], received 104 votes and the government's candidate, [[Francis ole Kaparo]], received 99 votes; in the second round Marende received 104 votes and Kaparo received 102. Although a two-thirds majority was required in the first two rounds, subsequently only a simple majority was required, and Marende was elected in the third round with 105 votes against 101 for Kaparo. Meanwhile, it was announced that Annan's visit would be delayed for a few days because he had fallen ill with the flu.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7190043.stm| work=BBC News| title=Kenya opposition boosted by vote| date=January 15, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118152903/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7190043.stm| archivedate=January 18, 2008| df=mdy-all}} In Nairobi threats and killings were carried out against the Asian and white Kenyan minorities by the banned ethnic sect Mungiki, which prompted a temporary exodus of the minority groups, until their protection was guaranteed by the government, prompting further economic hardship in the country. The ODM's planned protests, intended to last for three days, began on January 16,. Police met the protests with force and prevented them from reaching Uhuru Park in Nairobi; protests also took place in other parts of the country, including Kisumu and Eldoret. At least two people were reported killed in Kisumu as police used live ammunition against the protesters, along with tear gas.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/654F01F3-E0C9-4DF9-A365-BD1B20F94ABF.htm "Kenyan police shoot dead protesters"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119100843/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/654F01F3-E0C9-4DF9-A365-BD1B20F94ABF.htm |date=January 19, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, January 16, 2008.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7192958.stm| work=BBC News| title=Odinga denies 'ethnic cleansing'| date=January 16, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119174905/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7192958.stm| archivedate=January 19, 2008| df=mdy-all}} Odinga, in an interview with BBC's ''[[HARDtalk]]'', responded to Justice Minister [[Martha Karua]]'s earlier claim that the ODM had planned "ethnic cleansing" by saying that her accusation was "outrageous" and that the violence perpetrated by his supporters was a reaction to the actions of the police, who he said had been ordered to shoot "members of certain ethnic communities". The protests continued on January 17, with police continuing to use force against them. Government spokesman Alfred Mutua said that the government would not be swayed by the threats of development partners to withdraw aid. A train was looted in Kibera by residents due to shortages caused by the crisis.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/18/world/africa/18kenya.html |work=The New York Times |first1=Jeffrey |last1=Gettleman |first2=Kennedy |last2=Abwao |title=Protesters Clash With Police in Kenya and Loot Train |date=January 18, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310092110/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/18/world/africa/18kenya.html |archivedate=March 10, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Odinga alleged that police killed seven people in Nairobi, while the police spokesman, Eric Kiraithe, said that the police were acting lawfully and were showing restraint because the protesters were being "used by politicians". The ODM said that after the last day of protest on January 18, it would focus on boycotting companies controlled by Kibaki's allies.[http://www.myjoyonline.com/politics/200801/12603.asp "Kenya braced for further protests"], BBC (myjoyonline.com), January 18, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080122054649/http://www.myjoyonline.com/politics/200801/12603.asp |date=January 22, 2008 }} By January 18, at least 22 people were reported to have been killed in the three-day protests, with the last day seeing the most deaths. The protests were considered to be substantially diminished in strength compared to those in late December.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/18/ap/world/main3729303.shtml |work=CBS News |title=Protests Substantially Diminished in Strength }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} On January 19, despite the ODM's earlier announcement that it would cease protests, it said that protests would resume on January 24.[http://www.voanews.com/english/2008-01-19-voa16.cfm "Kenyan Opposition Calls for Another Demonstration Thursday"], VOA News, January 19, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080122122301/http://www.voanews.com/english/2008-01-19-voa16.cfm |date=January 22, 2008 }} ===Boycott and further violence=== [[File:GSU - Uhuru Park.jpg|thumb|300px|Police cordon off Uhuru Park to bar opposition from holding a mass protest rally]] Further violence in Nairobi and the Rift Valley followed the protests. On January 21, Minister of State for Internal Security [[George Saitoti]] warned against further protests, saying that they would only be "an opportunity for criminals to loot and commit other crimes" and that "illegal acts will be dealt with accordingly".Andrew Cawthorne and Wangui Kanina, [http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Kenya_government_turns_on_critics.html?siteSect=143&sid=8643744&cKey=1200920010000&ty=ti "Kenya government turns on critics"]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=The Rambling Man |fix-attempted=yes }}, Reuters (swissinfo), January 21, 2008. {{dead link|date=September 2011}} The government also said in reference to the opposition's planned boycott that it was illegal to "sabotage" businesses. The businesses targeted for the boycott included Equity Bank, [[Brookside Dairies]], CityHoppa, and Kenya Bus; it was speculated that the boycott would not have a substantial impact and that many Kenyans would find it too impractical to observe. Foreign Minister [[Moses Wetangula]], in reaction to criticism from the United Kingdom, summoned the UK's High Commissioner to complain, and he said that "our elections don't need a stamp of authority from the House of Commons".[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E3DF64AE-4A27-40C7-A4C0-E7715FF24B09.htm "Kenya opposition in boycott plan"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080401132833/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E3DF64AE-4A27-40C7-A4C0-E7715FF24B09.htm |date=April 1, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, January 21, 2008. Annan arrived in Kenya on January 22,.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=87&art_id=nw20080122225556932C666687 "Annan calls for fresh talks in Kenya"], Reuters (''IOL''), January 22, 2008. [https://www.webcitation.org/5nDtdeHqr?url=http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1 Archived copy] at [[WebCite]] (February 1, 2010). On January 23, the ODM held a memorial service in Nairobi for victims of the violence, at which Odinga said that tribes should not fight because "this is a war between the people of Kenya and a very small bloodthirsty clique clinging to power". Meanwhile, police fired tear gas at some of his supporters outside; some tear gas affected the mourning service, dispersing it. The state-owned telecommunications building was attacked and set on fire.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/23/ap/world/main3744372.shtml |work=CBS News |title=State-Owned Telecommunications Building Attacked }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} On the same day, Kibaki and Odinga met separately with Ugandan President [[Yoweri Museveni]],{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/24/ap/world/main3747884.shtml |work=CBS News |title=Kibaki and Odinga Meet with Ugandan President }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} and according to Museveni's press secretary an agreement was reached in principle to establish a judicial commission that would investigate the accusations of vote rigging; however, the two sides disagreed as to whether the government alone should appoint the members of the commission. Museveni was also said to have proposed a power-sharing deal, which was rejected by the government on the grounds that it was unwilling to share power with the ODM due to the latter's alleged responsibility for the killing of innocent people.[http://allafrica.com/stories/200801231038.html "Kenya: Museveni Proposes Power Sharing Deal to Raila, Kibaki"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002131639/http://allafrica.com/stories/200801231038.html |date=October 2, 2012 }}, ''The Monitor'' (allAfrica.com), January 24, 2008. Annan also met with Odinga, and the latter agreed to cancel the protests that were to have been held the next day.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E8539B90-68A5-47E4-B3EF-72600663B789.htm "Rival Kenyan leaders hold talks"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080127160535/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E8539B90-68A5-47E4-B3EF-72600663B789.htm |date=January 27, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, January 24, 2008. ===Beginning of talks, killing of MPs=== Kibaki and Odinga met for the first time since the crisis began on January 24, together with Annan.{{cite news | url=http://news.smh.com.au/kenyan-rivals-meeting-very-encouraging-says-former-un-chief/20080125-1o0x.html | archive-url=https://archive.is/20121231010921/http://news.smh.com.au/kenyan-rivals-meeting-very-encouraging-says-former-un-chief/20080125-1o0x.html | dead-url=yes | archive-date=December 31, 2012 | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | first=Irene | last=Wamaru | title=15 killed, curfew set in strife-torn western Kenya | date=January 25, 2008 | accessdate=April 13, 2008 }} Annan called the meeting "very encouraging", saying that it represented "the first steps towards a peaceful solution of the problem". Kibaki and Odinga both said after the meeting that they were working towards a solution and urged the people to be peaceful. On January 25, Odinga said in an interview that a power-sharing deal was out of the question, and that the only possibilities acceptable to him were that Kibaki resign or that a new election be held. Responding to a claim by Human Rights Watch that ODM leaders were orchestrating violence, he said that the people were reacting spontaneously.{{cite news | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/25/ap/world/main3753786.shtml |work=CBS News |title=ODM leaders Orchestrating Violence |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080203071918/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/25/ap/world/main3753786.shtml |archivedate=February 3, 2008 |deadurl=yes}} As violence continued in the Rift Valley, Annan asked both sides to designate negotiators by January 29,.[http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Annan_presses_Kenyan_rivals_to_end_bloodshed.html?siteSect=143&sid=8643744&cKey=1201565307000&ty=ti "Annan presses Kenyan rivals to end bloodshed"], Reuters (swissinfo.ch), January 28, 2008. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Meanwhile, serious violence broke out in [[Nakuru]] on January 24–25, apparently as a reaction to Kibaki describing himself as the "duly elected president" after meeting in person with Odinga. Kikuyus were attacked and a number of buildings were set on fire, along with Nakuru's only fire engine; at least 12 deaths were reported. Another town, [[Total Station]], was half-destroyed in violence between Kikuyus and Kalenjin, with at least two deaths reported, and as many as 50,000 people fled from violence near Molo. By January 27, at least 55 people had been killed in Nakuru, along with at least five in Kaptembwa and Sewage, two slums near Nakuru, while at least nine deaths were reported in [[Naivasha]], where Kikuyus set Luo homes on fire.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/27/world/main3756065.shtml |work=CBS News |title=Dozens Dead In New Kenya Election Violence |date=January 27, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329050757/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/27/world/main3756065.shtml |archivedate=March 29, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} By January 28, at least 64 people had been killed in Nakuru and at least 22 in Naivasha; 19 of the deaths in Naivasha occurred when Kikuyus set fire to a place where Luos had fled for safety.{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2008-01-28-kenya-unrest_N.htm | work=USA Today | title=Ethnic bloodletting spreads in Kenya | date=January 29, 2008 | accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080201084047/http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2008-01-28-kenya-unrest_N.htm | archivedate=February 1, 2008 | df=mdy-all }} ODM chairperson [[Henry Kosgei]] accused the government of facilitating the killing in Nakuru by imposing a curfew, which he said was used "to keep some groups indoors to be killed", on January 28,.[http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_2260148,00.html "Kibaki facing genocide claims"], AFP (News24), January 28, 2008. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080129134725/http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0%2C%2C2-11-1447_2260148%2C00.html |date=January 29, 2008 }} [[Mugabe Were]], an ODM Member of Parliament, was shot and killed early on January 29, 2008. Renewed protests and violence followed his death. Addressing the National Assembly before beginning talks, Annan called for an end to the "downward spiral into chaos that is threatening this beautiful country."{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/01/29/kenya.violence/ |title=Annan begs for calm in Kenya after lawmaker's killing |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307170123/http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/01/29/kenya.violence/ |archivedate=March 7, 2008 |deadurl=yes}} The talks then began, although they were delayed by 90 minutes due to disputed seating arrangements. Annan said that resolution of short-term issues might occur in four weeks, although he thought deeper talks might continue for a year.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7215673.stm| work=BBC News| title=Annan leads Kenyan crisis talks| date=January 29, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080202060716/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7215673.stm| archivedate=February 2, 2008| df=mdy-all}} Another ODM MP, [[David Kimutai Too]], was shot and killed by a policeman in Eldoret on January 31, 2008.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/01/world/africa/01kenya.html |work=The New York Times |first=Jeffrey |last=Gettleman |title=Second Lawmaker Is Killed as Kenya's Riots Intensify |date=February 1, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309231027/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/01/world/africa/01kenya.html |archivedate=March 9, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=87&art_id=nw20080131162805827C111269 "Kenya talks suspended after shooting"], AFP (''IOL''), January 31, 2008. [https://www.webcitation.org/5nDtdeHqr?url=http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1 Archived copy] at [[WebCite]] (February 1, 2010). Police said the killing was related to a love triangle involving him, the officer who shot him, and a female officer, but the ODM called it an assassination, accusing the government of seeking to reduce the number of ODM Members of Parliament, and protests and violence broke out. The talks were postponed until the next day due to the killing. ===Continued negotiations, signing of power-sharing agreement=== [[File:ODM - Raila Odinga supporters.jpg|thumb|right|ODM supporters at a political rally during the crisis]] UN Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-Moon]] arrived in Kenya for a visit to assist the talks on February 1.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/6EB4D30C-5E13-4918-BFBD-886F07B3E777.htm "UN chief backs Kenya talks"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080202051655/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/6EB4D30C-5E13-4918-BFBD-886F07B3E777.htm |date=February 2, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 1, 2008. During the same day, Annan announced that the two rival leaders had agreed on an agenda for peace talks, which included both short-term and long-term goals. The talks would last a month and would include the topics of ending the violence, the humanitarian situation, resolving the political crisis, and land and historical injustices. Annan said that he believed the first three of these four points could be resolved within seven to 15 days, and he said that an agreement had been reached on 18 measures to end the violence, including the demobilization of gangs and ceasing speeches and text messages that incite hatred and violence.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7223200.stm| work=BBC News| title=Kenyan parties 'agree peace plan'| date=February 1, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207035934/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7223200.stm| archivedate=February 7, 2008| df=mdy-all}} Violence nevertheless continued; on the next day at least 20 people were reported to have been killed since the agreement.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7224214.stm| work=BBC News| title=Violence follows Kenya peace plan| date=February 2, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206135121/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7224214.stm| archivedate=February 6, 2008| df=mdy-all}} On February 3, Odinga called for African Union peacekeepers to be sent to Kenya.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7A56C073-43E4-49DA-930C-99CFBCCBE3BE.htm "Odinga urges peacekeepers for Kenya"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080204032654/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7A56C073-43E4-49DA-930C-99CFBCCBE3BE.htm |date=February 4, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 3, 2008. South Africa's [[Cyril Ramaphosa]] was unanimously chosen by Annan's team as chief mediator to lead long-term talks,[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/0B264046-B4C2-415D-966F-D6F70D1A43EE.htm "Kenya rejects S African mediator"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207125543/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/0B264046-B4C2-415D-966F-D6F70D1A43EE.htm |date=February 7, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 4, 2008. but the government had concerns about Ramaphosa's involvement, saying that he and Odinga had business links. Ramaphosa consequently withdrew from the talks and Annan accepted his withdrawal on February 4,. Odinga said on the same day that the ODM would withdraw from the talks if a deal was not reached, and he said that his party wanted a new presidential election to be held within three months, with a new electoral commission and the same voter register. The alternative possibility of a transitional coalition government, in which a new position of Prime Minister would be created for Odinga and Kibaki's power would be reduced, was something Odinga said he could consider, although it was not the option he preferred.Fiana Forde, [http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=vn20080205111631860C283390 "Withdrawal threat to peace talks"], ''Daily News'' (South Africa), February 5, 2008, page 5. [https://www.webcitation.org/5nDtdeHqr?url=http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1 Archived copy] at [[WebCite]] (February 1, 2010). Opposing plans for a meeting of foreign ministers from the countries of the East African [[Intergovernmental Authority on Development]] (IGAD) in Kenya, Nyongo said that the ODM would hold protests if the meeting went ahead, believing that the meeting would be a means to legitimize Kibaki's government. Annan was critical of this threat, saying that "provocative statements outside negotiations" were supposed to be avoided.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/37086AF4-CC11-4079-A4BC-45034E6BF7B4.htm "Kenya opposition threatens protests"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208060851/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/37086AF4-CC11-4079-A4BC-45034E6BF7B4.htm |date=February 8, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 5, 2008. The government subsequently said that the meeting would not officially be considered an IGAD meeting, and the ODM called off the protests on February 6,.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=nw20080207064044143C751931 "East African statesmen converge in Kenya"], AFP (''IOL''), February 7, 2008. [https://www.webcitation.org/5nDtdeHqr?url=http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1 Archived copy] at [[WebCite]] (February 1, 2010). On February 7, the two sides remained deeply divided in talks, although they agreed that there should not be a recount of votes. Annan said that he was "totally opposed to a re-election in this climate", referring to the persistent violence. Meanwhile, the [[United Nations Security Council]] called for peaceful resolution of the dispute through negotiations, the United States imposed a travel ban on ten unnamed Kenyans (a move that was praised by Kibaki's government), and a policeman, Edward Kirui, was arrested for allegedly shooting two protesters to death in Kisumu on January 16,.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7232372.stm| work=BBC News| title=Murder charges for Kenya police| date=February 7, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213022031/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7232372.stm| archivedate=February 13, 2008| df=mdy-all}} Progress in the talks was reported on February 8, with Annan saying that both sides had agreed on the need for a political settlement[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/40824002-25B1-4CDB-8BAB-19D18437827C.htm "Kenya parties see progress"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209114131/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/40824002-25B1-4CDB-8BAB-19D18437827C.htm |date=February 9, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 8, 2008.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7235038.stm| work=BBC News| title=Progress at Kenya's peace talks| date=February 8, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080211194910/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7235038.stm| archivedate=February 11, 2008| df=mdy-all}} and that he hoped talks on point three (the resolution of the political crisis) could be concluded early in the next week. The ODM's [[William Ruto]] said that although there was progress, a solution had still not been reached, and he denied that a national unity government had been agreed upon; Mutula Kilonzo, a negotiator for the government, reported "excellent" progress. Saitoti, the Internal Security Minister, announced the end of the ban on rallies on the same day due to improved security, but said that rallies must be held only for peaceful purposes. Despite the reported progress and his earlier adoption of a more conciliatory tone, Odinga returned to a hard-line stance on February 9, repeating his earlier demand that Kibaki should either resign or a new election should be held, and he said that he would not compromise on that point.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,330212,00.html |publisher=Fox News |title=Kenyan Opposition Leader Demands President's Resignation |date=February 9, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408113806/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0%2C2933%2C330212%2C00.html |archivedate=April 8, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Speaking before the National Assembly on February 12, Annan said that both sides in the talks had agreed to set up "an independent review committee that will be mandated to investigate all aspects of the 2007 presidential election".[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=87&art_id=nw20080212104451895C531118 "Kenya panel to probe disputed elections"], AFP (''IOL''), February 12, 2008. [https://www.webcitation.org/5nDtdeHqr?url=http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1 Archived copy] at [[WebCite]] (February 1, 2010). He also said that both sides in the National Assembly would have to work together to pass legislation needed to resolve the crisis. On the same day, as talks approached a potential agreement, talks were moved to a secret location, with Annan requesting a "complete news blackout" and asking participants in the talks to not disclose what was under discussion. Ruto said that the ODM had proposed forming a government in which the two sides would share power for two years before a new election.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/090394BF-FD56-4672-9FB6-E92A2F39B617.htm "Kenya rivals in power-sharing talks"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214145605/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/090394BF-FD56-4672-9FB6-E92A2F39B617.htm |date=February 14, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 12, 2008. Although Annan suggested that the two sides had agreed to a two-year power-sharing transitional government, the government objected, with the Justice Minister, Martha Karua, saying that this suggestion had misrepresented and undermined the government's position. On February 13, the mediators said in a statement that Annan had only expressed his own perspective and that he had not meant to suggest that the two sides had formally agreed on the proposal.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7242451.stm| work=BBC News| title=Kenya government anger with Annan| date=February 13, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080217210424/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7242451.stm| archivedate=February 17, 2008| df=mdy-all}} As talks adjourned on February 14, scheduled to resume the following week, government negotiator Kilonzo said that an agreement had been reached to restart the process of writing a new constitution after it had stalled following the failure of the 2005 constitutional referendum.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/110B62FA-08AB-4073-A713-95E0ED73980D.htm "Kenyans to 'rewrite constitution'"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219234225/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/110B62FA-08AB-4073-A713-95E0ED73980D.htm |date=February 19, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 14, 2008. On February 15, Annan said that the two sides had agreed to a range of reforms, including the improvement of electoral laws and human rights, as well as a review of the constitution, although they had yet to agree upon the composition of a power-sharing government. It was reported that the government side wanted Kibaki to retain strong executive powers, while the opposition wanted Odinga to have extensive powers in a new position of Prime Minister. According to Annan, they were about to take "the last difficult and frightening step" to conclude a deal, and he said that he intended to remain in Kenya until a new government was in place, by which time he thought the process would be "irreversible". The commission charged with reviewing the election was to be established by March 15, with a report to follow within three to six months.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/D8C3E21B-4086-46CF-B03F-0F46CEE3853E.htm "Kenya peace deal 'very close'"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220022358/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/D8C3E21B-4086-46CF-B03F-0F46CEE3853E.htm |date=February 20, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 15, 2008. U.S. Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]] arrived in Kenya to support the talks on February 18. Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Wetangula said that help was welcome but he stressed that ultimately the problem had to be solved by Kenyans and that no one should make the "mistake of putting a gun to anybody's head and saying 'either/or'" in an attempt to force a solution. Rice met with Kibaki, Odinga, and Annan, and she emphasized the importance of reaching a settlement, saying that one should have already been in place; however, she also said that the U.S. was not trying to "dictate a solution to Kenyans".[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/039B5239-0509-4B7C-A20E-21805111F7D7.htm "Rice calls for Kenya power-sharing"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220204345/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/039B5239-0509-4B7C-A20E-21805111F7D7.htm |date=February 20, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 18, 2008. On February 19, Kibaki said that, while he was willing to share power in the government, an agreement should be made in the context of the existing constitution. Nyongo then called for the National Assembly to be summoned within a week "to enact the necessary changes in the constitution to implement these mediation proposals", warning that the ODM would otherwise resume protests.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/FC393B57-D8B2-4B7C-B231-29EB21ECC766.htm "Kenya opposition threatens protests"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080222170629/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/FC393B57-D8B2-4B7C-B231-29EB21ECC766.htm |date=February 22, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 20, 2008. On February 21, Mutula Kilonzo said that the government side had accepted "the creation of the post of a non-executive prime minister with substantial responsibilities", but the opposition wanted the prime minister to be a head of government with executive powers. Nyongo said that he thought an agreement would be reached by the next day.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/8177B4E6-7D05-425A-B31C-41E3448F3EFC.htm "Kenyan parties tackle PM problem"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228014219/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/8177B4E6-7D05-425A-B31C-41E3448F3EFC.htm |date=February 28, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 21, 2008. On February 21, [[East African Community]] Secretary-General [[Juma Mwapachu]] said that the crisis was having a negative effect on the regional economy. Speaking in Nairobi on February 22, newly elected [[Chairman of the African Union Commission]] [[Jean Ping]] said it was hoped that an agreement would be reached by the next week.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7258349.stm| work=BBC News| title=AU head urges Kenya peace deal| date=February 22, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080225132312/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7258349.stm| archivedate=February 25, 2008| df=mdy-all}}[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/6309E706-82A1-4DA1-8BD0-87B093E4931C.htm "AU chief urges Kenya political deal"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228014148/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/6309E706-82A1-4DA1-8BD0-87B093E4931C.htm |date=February 28, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 22, 2008. An impasse was reached on February 25, 2008. While both parties agreed to the creation of the post of prime minister, they disagreed about the powers the newly created post should have, over government posts and over a possible election in case the coalition should split.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7263359.stm |work=BBC News |title=Annan frustrated by Kenya talks |date=February 25, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080303064237/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7263359.stm |archivedate=March 3, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Annan declared the talks suspended on February 26, saying that they had "not broken down" but that the leaders needed to "become directly engaged in these talks". Mutula Kilonzo said that media reports of supposed deals had caused problems and complained of unfair pressure. The ODM's Mudavadi expressed frustration at the situation.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7265234.stm |work=BBC News |title=Kenya poll crisis talks suspended |date=February 26, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080303210249/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7265234.stm |archivedate=March 3, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} [[Jakaya Kikwete]], the President of [[Tanzania]] and [[Chairperson of the African Union|Chairman]] of the [[African Union]], arrived in Kenya on February 27, to assist in the talks. On the same day, Odinga said that the ODM had decided not to resume protests as planned on February 28, expressing continued commitment to the talks.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/05A58B43-D3F2-407A-B7B5-7EB16FC5EA7F.htm "Kenya opposition calls off protests"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080302022520/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/05A58B43-D3F2-407A-B7B5-7EB16FC5EA7F.htm |date=March 2, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, February 27, 2008. On February 28, Kibaki and Odinga signed the agreement meant to end the crisis at a ceremony in Nairobi;[http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/02/28/africa/AF-GEN-Kenya-Election-Violence.php "Kenya's rival politicians reach an agreement"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314225949/http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/02/28/africa/AF-GEN-Kenya-Election-Violence.php |date=March 14, 2008 }}, Associated Press (''International Herald Tribune''), February 28, 2008. Annan said that the agreement was to be known as the [[National Accord and Reconciliation Act 2008|National Accord and Reconciliation Act]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7269476.stm |work=BBC News |title=Key points: Kenya power-sharing deal |date=February 28, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080406001538/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7269476.stm |archivedate=April 6, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} The two leaders agreed to form a [[coalition government]], with Odinga set to receive the new position of Prime Minister, in which capacity he is to "coordinate and supervise government affairs"; it remained unclear whether, as Prime Minister, he could still be overruled by Kibaki. According to the agreement, the Prime Minister must be an elected member of the National Assembly as well as the parliamentary leader of the party or coalition holding a majority of seats in the National Assembly. The agreement also provides for two Deputy Prime Ministers, one for each of the two parties, while the allotment of Cabinet portfolios is to reflect the relative strength of the respective parties in the National Assembly. The Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Ministers can only be removed from their positions if they lose a no-confidence vote in the National Assembly. Kibaki said that he would reconvene the National Assembly on March 6, so that it could make the constitutional changes needed in order to implement the agreement. ===Implementation of the agreement=== Annan left Kenya on March 2, leaving [[Oluyemi Adeniji]], a former Nigerian Foreign Minister, to lead talks on remaining issues, such as land, political reforms, and the uneven [[distribution of wealth]] between various ethnic groups.[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gmh1s7-AqA1Bt9Wl1SVFKtOpxS6Q "Kenyan crisis talks to resume without deal-broker Annan"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520122445/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gmh1s7-AqA1Bt9Wl1SVFKtOpxS6Q |date=May 20, 2011 }}, AFP, March 3, 2008. On 3, March 13, people were killed in an attack near [[Mount Elgon]] that was attributed by police to the [[Sabaot Land Defence Force]]. Kibaki and Odinga met again on March 4, as part of the follow-up negotiations.
