Odinga said that this meeting was "very productive".[http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_2281877,00.html "Kenya crisis talks continue"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080311000025/http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_2281877,00.html |date=March 11, 2008 }}, Associated Press (News24.com), March 4, 2008. {{cite web |url=http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0%2C%2C2-11-1447_2281877%2C00.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080311000025/http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0%2C%2C2-11-1447_2281877%2C00.html |archivedate=March 11, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} On March 6, rights groups including [[Reporters Without Borders]] stated that the Kenyan media played a positive role during the violence despite being inexperienced with such situations.{{cite news |url=http://africa.reuters.com/top/news/usnBAN656314.html |title=rights groups commend kenyan media |publisher=Africa.reuters.com |date=February 9, 2009 |accessdate=May 1, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080309213345/http://africa.reuters.com/top/news/usnBAN656314.html |archivedate=March 9, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} Speaking in the National Assembly when it convened on March 6, Kibaki urged it to quickly pass the legislation required to implement the power-sharing agreement; he said that the people were watching and that they wanted to see "pragmatic solutions, not ideological posturing". He named four bills that the National Assembly needed to pass: the National Accord and Reconciliation Bill, a bill amending the constitution, a bill establishing [[The Truth, Justice and Reconciliation Commission of Kenya|the truth, justice and reconciliation commission]], and a bill dealing with ethnic issues.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/2C7EF2B4-C80B-4C6F-9776-2D9F7EB66896.htm "Kenya leader urges backing for deal"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308124931/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/2C7EF2B4-C80B-4C6F-9776-2D9F7EB66896.htm |date=March 8, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, March 6, 2008. On March 9–10, the army attacked the Sabaot Land Defence Force near Mount Elgon; this attack included aerial bombardment. 30,000 people were reported to have fled from the army's attack, although this number was disputed and the army said that it was "not intimidating or harassing residents".[http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/03/10/news/Kenya.php "Kenyan army crackdown reported in west; parliament to debate power-sharing agreement"], Associated Press (''International Herald Tribune''), March 10, 2008. On March 10,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7288900.stm |work=BBC News |title=Kenya MPs try to fast-track bills |date=March 11, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080321122813/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7288900.stm |archivedate=March 21, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} [[Francis Muthaura]], the head of the public service, stirred controversy by saying that Kibaki would remain both head of state and head of government[http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=2&newsid=118828 "Protests at Muthaura’s power deal talk"] {{dead link|date=March 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, ''Daily Nation'', March 12, 2008. and that Odinga would only rank third in the government, after Kibaki and Vice-President Musyoka. Government negotiator KilonzoBarney Jopson, [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/26c93132-efd9-11dc-8a17-0000779fd2ac.html "Challenge to Odinga role threatens Kenya pact"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111111044205/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/26c93132-efd9-11dc-8a17-0000779fd2ac.html |date=November 11, 2011 }}, ''Financial Times'', March 12, 2008. and Foreign Minister Wetangula backed this interpretation of the agreement, with the latter saying that "we are not setting up a government within a government". The ODM, however, angrily rejected Muthaura's interpretation. William Ruto said that "Kenyans should treat Mr Muthaura's statement with the contempt it deserves" and that it was "uncalled for, unnecessary and contemptuous of the agreement". ODM spokesman Salim Lome said that it was unacceptable to have Odinga ranking third, as "a minor hanger-on", and that the ODM would never have agreed to such an arrangement. On March 11, a parliamentary committee made a request for the bills implementing the agreement to be fast-tracked, which would provide for them to be considered within five days, rather than two weeks. The National Assembly passed two bills implementing the agreement on March 18,. The first of these was the Constitution of Kenya (Amendment) Bill, which passed unanimously with 200 votes in favor; this constitutionally established the posts of Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Minister. The amendment was followed by a law providing for those posts in a new government and detailing the terms of the power-sharing arrangement. Kibaki signed the bills into law a few hours later. He said that he was "now confident a permanent solution to the crisis will be achieved" and called for the drafting of a new constitution; meanwhile, Odinga called for a "national ethnic conference where we will have representatives from all the 42 tribes in the country come together to discuss openly how we want to lead this country".[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/C3806220-67C8-4033-9A6D-A7223B0CED65.htm "Kenyan leader signs power-share law"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080319210230/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/C3806220-67C8-4033-9A6D-A7223B0CED65.htm |date=March 19, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, March 18, 2008. As part of consultations on the composition of the new Cabinet, the ODM proposed a Cabinet with 34 members (twice the number in the partial Cabinet named by Kibaki in January), while the government proposed a Cabinet with 44 members. On April 1, a protest of about 100 people was held in Nairobi against these proposals on the grounds that it was unaffordable to have so many ministers and that having them would not serve a constructive purpose; the protesters demanded that the Cabinet be limited to no more than 24 members. This protest was broken up by police with tear gas.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/F8B82C7C-A25B-4A03-BFE0-12E4A05899DC.htm "Kenyan police break up protest"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080404033928/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/F8B82C7C-A25B-4A03-BFE0-12E4A05899DC.htm |date=April 4, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, April 1, 2008. In a statement on April 2, Annan expressed concerns about the length of time that it was taking to name a new Cabinet. He urged Kibaki and Odinga to put the national interest first, conclude consultations, and name a Cabinet with an equal division of power in line with the agreement.[http://apanews.net/apa.php?page=show_article_eng&id_article=59561 "Kofi Annan worried about sluggishness in naming new Kenyan cabinet"], African Press Agency, April 2, 2008. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} On April 3, the two sides announced that they had reached an agreement on the size and composition of the Cabinet. According to a statement from Kibaki's office, the new Cabinet would have 40 ministers, would be announced on April 6, and would be sworn in on April 12,.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/97982F33-F229-4527-80A3-255C23CCE9F6.htm "Kenya rivals break ministry impasse"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080405083444/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/97982F33-F229-4527-80A3-255C23CCE9F6.htm |date=April 5, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, April 3, 2008. This Cabinet would be the largest in Kenya's history, and the announcement of its size was greeted with substantial dissatisfaction among the people, with many believing a 40-member Cabinet to be wasteful, unnecessary, and intended merely to provide additional jobs with which to reward politicians. The government argued that the large size of the Cabinet was needed in order for it to be properly inclusive. Alfred Mutua, the government spokesman, said that "there is no price that is too high for our country to ensure peace, harmony and reconciliation, healing and stability that will spur and grow the economy and create even more wealth", and he suggested that the cost would not be as great as anticipated because "most of the new ministries are subdivided from formerly existing ministries and therefore the budget and members of staff for those new ministries already exist."[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/D809BD8B-4545-4C37-99BF-4A6F128C5F74.htm "Kenya cabinet delayed over posts"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080406202946/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/D809BD8B-4545-4C37-99BF-4A6F128C5F74.htm |date=April 6, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, April 5, 2008. On April 5, the day before the Cabinet was to be announced, the ODM said that the announcement had been delayed because there was still disagreement on the allotment of ministerial portfolios. The disagreement reportedly hinged on the particularly important portfolios of finance, local government, energy, and internal security. According to the government, the finance, defence, foreign affairs, and justice portfolios were to go to Kibaki's party, the PNU, while the ODM was to receive the roads, public works, tourism, and agriculture portfolios. Mutua said that Odinga had not submitted his list of proposed ministers to Kibaki, and he said that Kibaki had invited Odinga for talks on the morning of April 6,. Kibaki and Odinga accordingly met, and afterwards they said in a joint statement that they had made "substantial progress" and that they expected an agreement to be reached in further talks on April 7,.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7333050.stm |work=BBC News |title=No deal in Kenyan cabinet talks |date=April 7, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409230842/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7333050.stm |archivedate=April 9, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} However, on April 8, the talks were suspended due to the continued disagreement; according to Nyongo, they were suspended "until [the PNU] fully recognises the 50/50 power-sharing arrangement and the principle of portfolio balance". Odinga said that he had received a letter from the PNU, which asserted that "the constitution grants the president exclusive executive powers to run his country on his own and ... his powers supersede the provisions of the accord". Meanwhile, a protest in Kibera was broken up by police with tear gas; this was the largest protest to occur since the agreement was signed.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/36FA024F-C85B-4E2B-84DB-3F6838CB70C7.htm "Kenya opposition suspends talks"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409125445/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/36FA024F-C85B-4E2B-84DB-3F6838CB70C7.htm |date=April 9, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, April 8, 2008. It was reported on April 12, that Kibaki and Odinga had reached an agreement on the Cabinet and that it would be announced on the next day.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E06B539F-AB6E-4CCA-9BEA-7D9E42ED0E6D.htm "Kenyan leaders reach cabinet deal"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080413150112/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E06B539F-AB6E-4CCA-9BEA-7D9E42ED0E6D.htm |date=April 13, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, April 12, 2008. Accordingly, the Cabinet, with 40 ministers{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7345318.stm |work=BBC News |title=Kenya unveils coalition cabinet |date=April 13, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415232757/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7345318.stm |archivedate=April 15, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}Patrick Wachira, [http://www.eastandard.net/news/?id=1143984813 "Kibaki names new Cabinet"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415144844/http://www.eastandard.net/news/?id=1143984813 |date=April 15, 2008 }}, ''The Standard'' (Kenya), April 14, 2008. and 50 assistant ministers, was named on April 13,; there were 20 ministers each for PNU and the ODM. The PNU was considered to have kept most of the main portfolios despite the dispute that led to the delay, and some in the ODM complained that because of this there was not a true balance in portfolios. The PNU took portfolios such as foreign affairs, finance, internal security, defence, and energy, while the ODM took portfolios such as local government, agriculture, immigration, roads, and public works. Odinga was named Prime Minister, Uhuru Kenyatta was named as the PNU's Deputy Prime Minister (as well as Minister of Trade), and Musalia Mudavadi was named as the ODM's Deputy Prime Minister (as well as Minister of Local Government). Kibaki challenged politicians to put politics aside and "get to work". Odinga and the Cabinet were sworn in on April 17, 2008 at State House. Annan travelled to Kenya again for the occasion; he called on Kenyans to support the new Cabinet and, noting that there was "still a long way to go", said that the next task would be to "mould the cabinet as a cohesive, effective and productive thing that will help steer this nation right". ===After the formation of the unity government=== In the absence of an opposition due to the formation of the coalition government, more than 70 backbencher MPs supported the creation of a coalition opposition, feeling that it was important to have an opposition for the sake of democratic governance. However, on May 22, 2008, the Cabinet decided to oppose the creation of such an opposition, saying that it would be unconstitutional and would violate the spirit of the coalition. On the same day, the Cabinet decided to fast-track the commission of inqu your trash ry that is intended to investigate the causes of the violence.[http://apanews.net/apa.php?page=show_article_eng&id_article=64462 "Kenya: Government opposes formation of opposition"], African Press Agency, May 23, 2008. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} A proposed bill that would allow the backbenchers to create an official opposition (the National Assembly (Parliamentary Opposition) Bill 2008) was published in August 2008 and was passed a few months later.Alex Ndegwa, [http://www.eastandard.net/InsidePage.php?id=1143992680&cid=4 "‘Opposition’ MPs edge closer to recognition as Bill is published"], ''The Standard'' (Kenya), August 16, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113062815/http://www.eastandard.net/InsidePage.php?id=1143992680&cid=4 |date=January 13, 2015 }} In addition to the two vacancies in Parliament created by the killing of ODM MPs Mugabe Were and David Too, results were never announced in two parliamentary constituencies due to violence, and another vacancy was produced by the election of Kenneth Marende as Speaker of Parliament. The five by-elections to fill these seats were to be held on June 11, 2008. During the campaigning for the by-elections, which concluded on June 9, the politics of ethnicity was again evident, causing anxiety among some observers; increased tension was also evident between the PNU and the ODM. The ODM alleged that some PNU ministers were guilty of "openly bribing voters, intimidating ODM supporters and misusing state resources", and ODM minister [[William Ole Ntimama]] said that his party "watched with dismay as our coalition partners sink to new lows without any regard for the consequences which may flow". The issue of a possible amnesty for those arrested in connection with the violence also proved to be controversial. Vice-President Musyoka downplayed the tension, saying that campaigning had "not interfered in any way with the smooth operations of the coalition".[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=87&art_id=nw20080609190845942C967367 "Kenyan by-elections will test new coalition"], Sapa-AFP (''IOL''), June 9, 2008. [https://www.webcitation.org/5nDtdeHqr?url=http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1 Archived copy] at [[WebCite]] (February 1, 2010). On June 10, 2008, two ministers—Minister of Roads [[Kipkalya Kones]] and Assistant Minister of Home Affairs [[Lorna Laboso]]—were killed in a plane crash, leaving another two seats vacant.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=nw20080610182455856C880094 "Two Kenyan government ministers die"], Sapa-AFP (''IOL''), June 10, 2008. [https://www.webcitation.org/5nDtdeHqr?url=http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1 Archived copy] at [[WebCite]] (February 1, 2010). ==Casualties and displacement== By January 28, the death toll from the violence was at around 1,300.{{cite web|title=Al Jazeera English – News – Kenya Ethnic Clashes Intensify |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/CA34AA32-041D-497D-BE2B-A463562C6FFF.htm |accessdate=February 24, 2008 |year=2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220193929/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/CA34AA32-041D-497D-BE2B-A463562C6FFF.htm |archivedate=February 20, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/954C7498-65BE-4CEC-A71D-6B326D012E71.htm "Kenya police in 'shoot to kill' row"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905113349/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/954C7498-65BE-4CEC-A71D-6B326D012E71.htm |date=September 5, 2008 }}, Al Jazeera, January 13, 2008. Up to 600,000 people have been displaced.{{cite news |author= |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/02/11/world/main3815702.shtml |title=U.N.: 600,000 Displaced In Kenya Unrest |publisher=Cbsnews.com |date=February 11, 2008 |accessdate=May 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512055609/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/02/11/world/main3815702.shtml |archivedate=May 12, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news | title = Kenya opposition cancels protests | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7174670.stm | accessdate =February 24, 2008 |work=BBC News | date=January 7, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080110152443/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7174670.stm| archivedate= January 10, 2008 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7172868.stm| work=BBC News| title=Kibaki offer on unity government| date=January 5, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108072559/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7172868.stm| archivedate=January 8, 2008| df=mdy-all}} The largest single loss of life was when a church providing shelter from the violence to 200 people was set on fire by rioters, killing 35 people. The people who were sheltering were members of President Kibaki's tribe, the Kikuyu.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7167363.stm| work=BBC News| title=Kenya diplomatic push for peace| date=January 2, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105105252/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7167363.stm| archivedate=January 5, 2008| df=mdy-all}} Former Olympic athlete [[Lucas Sang]] died under unknown circumstances in a riot at [[Eldoret]] on January 1.''The Standard'', January 3, 2008: [http://eastandard.net/news/?id=1143979865&catid=39 Poll violence claim former athlete Sang] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080106125709/http://eastandard.net/news/?id=1143979865&catid=39 |date=January 6, 2008 }} Politician [[G. G. having a "shoot to kill" policy, using live ammunition against protesters and looters.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7186275.stm| work=BBC News| title=Kenya police used 'lethal force'| date=January 13, 2008| accessdate=April 13, 2008 | deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080116104303/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7186275.stm| archivedate=January 16, 2008| df=mdy-all}} According to the police, they have shot looters but not protesters. On January 18, police spokesman Eric Kiraithe said that 510 people had been killed in the violence and that 82 of them were killed by police.[http://allafrica.com/stories/200801180904.html "Kenya: Police Termed Kisumu Shooting Regrettable"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080122103433/http://allafrica.com/stories/200801180904.html |date=January 22, 2008 }}, ''The East African Standard'' (allAfrica.com), January 19, 2008. According to Kiraithe, the police were acting lawfully and were showing restraint because the protesters were being "used by politicians."{{cite web | work=Myjoyonline.com |title=Kenya braced for further protests | url=http://www.myjoyonline.com/politics/200801/12603.asp | accessdate =February 24, 2008 | year = 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080122054649/http://www.myjoyonline.com/politics/200801/12603.asp |archivedate = January 22, 2008}} Later in January, Human Rights Watch accused "ODM politicians and local leaders" of organizing, instigating and facilitating violence against Kikuyus.{{cite news | title = Kenyan ethnic attacks 'planned' | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7206658.stm | accessdate =February 24, 2008 |work=BBC News | date=January 24, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080307051922/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7206658.stm| archivedate= March 7, 2008 | deadurl= no}} The BBC reported on March 5, that government officials had met with members of the [[Mungiki]] militia, which is banned, at State House to arrange for the militia to protect Kiyukus. The government denied this.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7279149.stm |work=BBC News |title=State 'sanctioned' Kenyan clashes |date=March 5, 2008 |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080418025654/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7279149.stm |archivedate=April 18, 2008 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} ==Regional implications== The violence in Kenya has had serious economic ramifications throughout East Africa, particularly for the landlocked countries of the Great Lakes region ([[Uganda]], Rwanda, [[Burundi]], and eastern parts of the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]]).{{cite web | title = Kenya crisis: Spectre of economic collapse sends shivers through EA | url=http://www.nationmedia.com/EastAfrican/current/News/news070120081.htm | accessdate =February 24, 2008 | year = 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080109145953/http://www.nationmedia.com/eastafrican/current/News/news070120081.htm|archivedate=January 9, 2008 |deadurl=yes}} These countries depend upon Kenyan infrastructure links (particularly the port at [[Mombasa]]) for important imports as well as export routes. Significant shortages of gasoline were reported in [[Uganda]] as well as [[Zanzibar]] following the elections. The [[East African Community]], despite having election observers in Kenya, did not issue a statement. ==Reactions== A government spokesman claimed that Odinga's supporters were "engaging in [[ethnic cleansing]]". Odinga countered that Kibaki's camp was "guilty, directly, of [[genocide]]" as he called for international mediation.{{cite web | title = Raila takes the lead in search for a way out |work=The Standard |location=Hong Kong |url=http://www.eastandard.net/news/?id=1143979878&cid=4 | accessdate =February 24, 2008 | year = 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080207061448/http://www.eastandard.net/news/?id=1143979878&cid=4| archivedate= February 7, 2008 | deadurl= yes}} ==Possible continuation== The UN had warned that a repeat of the problems could occur after the [[Kenyan presidential election, 2013|next election]] unless Kenya strengthens its institutions and the perpetrators of the 2007 violence are punished. A BBC report in 2009 found that rival groups in [[Rift Valley Province]], such as the Kalenjin and Kikuyu, were purchasing firearms such as [[AK-47]] and [[Heckler & Koch G3|G3]] rifles, in readiness for anticipated violence at the 2013 poll.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8293745.stm |work=BBC News |title=Kenyans 'rearming for 2012 poll' |date=October 7, 2009 |accessdate=October 7, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007100851/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8293745.stm |archivedate=October 7, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} There is, however, concerted efforts from the civil society to help avert such an eventuality. There is even a campaign dubbed The Wazi Campaign,[[Wazi campaign]]The Wazi Campaign that aims to prevent the recurrence of the violence through the use of animated cartoon PSAs that preach peace. Despite these concerns, Kenya had a peaceful election in 2013 with a record 85.91% voter turnout.{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21723488 | work=BBC News | title=Kenya election: Uhuru Kenyatta wins presidency | date=March 9, 2013 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130312005656/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21723488 | archivedate=March {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox civil conflict |title = 2011 Northern Ireland riots |partof = |image = Belfast riots 2011 riot police.jpg |caption = Riot police and a burnt-out car in [[Ardoyne]] |date = 20 June 2011 – 16 July 2011 |place = [[Belfast]], [[Portadown]], [[Newry]], [[Ballyclare]], [[Larne]], [[Derry]], [[Ballymena]] |coordinates = |causes = |goals = |methods = [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]], [[riot]]ing, car burnings, houses damaged, gun battles |status = |result = * Protestant and Catholic houses damaged * Families evacuated * PSNI criticised for the way they tackled riots |side1 = |side2 = |side3 = |leadfigures1 = |leadfigures2 = |leadfigures3 = |howmany1 = |howmany2 = |howmany3 = |casualties1 = 300+ injuries |casualties2 = 50+ arrests |casualties3 = |casualties_label = |notes = }} The '''2011 Northern Ireland riots''' were a series of riots between 20 June 2011 and 16 July 2011, starting originally in [[Belfast]], before spreading to other parts of [[Northern Ireland]]. They were initiated by the [[Ulster Volunteer Force]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2011/jun/27/the-truth-about-belfasts-riots|title=The truth about Belfast's riots - Henry McDonald|first=Henry|last=McDonald|date=27 June 2011|website=Theguardian.com|accessdate=7 June 2016}}</ref>
==June riots== The sectarian violence began around 21:00 BST on the night of Monday 20 June, when a large number of [[Ulster loyalism|loyalists]] made their way from the [[Unionism in Ireland|unionist]] Mount and Castlereagh Street areas to the [[Irish nationalism|nationalist]] [[Short Strand]] enclave.<ref name="BBC3">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-13854027 BBC] – Belfast violence flares again as police attacked</ref> This provoked a response from the nationalists.<ref name="BBC3"/> The [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] (PSNI) [[Assistant Chief Constable]] Alistair Finlay said that around 500–600 people were involved in the rioting.<ref name="RTE">[http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0622/belfast.html RTE] – Call for urgent talks in Belfast communities</ref> According to the PSNI, the riots are said to have been initially instigated by the [[Ulster Volunteer Force]] (UVF).<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jun/22/belfast-riots-setback-peace-process The Guardian] – Belfast riots: a setback for area barely reshaped by peace process</ref><ref name="UTV">[http://www.u.tv/News/UVF-blamed-for-Belfast-riots/c76968fa-6384-410a-b853-9e9354e6f575 UTV] -UVF 'organised' east Belfast riot</ref>
The clashes saw various dangerous objects such as petrol bombs, bricks, bottles, fireworks and smoke bombs thrown by both sides in what police described as "high-level, life-threatening, organised, serious and sustained" attack by people "hell-bent on disorder".<ref name="UTV"/> At one point six shots were fired from the nationalist Short Strand area followed by about five shots from the loyalist Pitt Park.<ref name="UTV"/> Two shots hit a police [[Land Rover Tangi|Land Rover]] in what the PSNI claimed was attempted murder of their officers.<ref name="BBC3"/> One officer suffered eye injuries when a laser pen was being used to blind officers.<ref name="UTV"/>
The riots in Short Strand was described by politicians as the worst violence in the area in a decade.<ref>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2011/06/201162117510847754.html</ref>
On the Tuesday night, during further clashes between unionists and nationalists, about 700 people were involved. A photographer was shot in the leg by a gunman firing from the nationalist area, which police blamed on [[dissident republicans]].<ref name="RTE"/><ref name="BBC1">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-13886616 BBC] – Belfast flashpoint largely quiet after day of talks</ref><ref name="BBC2">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-13873307 BBC] – Police say dissidents behind photographer shooting</ref>
By Wednesday 22 June, discussions were held between community representatives, politicians, and loyalist and nationalist figures. The end result was for both sides to police their own communities to avoid further violence.{{cn|date=November 2015}} Later that night the area was largely peaceful despite unionist and nationalist groups – held back by community marshals – being involved for several hours in a stand-off at the Mountpottinger Road end of the Short Strand until around 01:30 on Thursday morning.<ref name="BBC1"/> Nationalist marshals intervened to stop nationalist youths attacking police Land Rovers.<ref name="BBC1"/>
A 20-year-old woman was arrested on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon and assaulting police,<ref name="RTE"/> which was followed on the Wednesday by the arrest of a 22-year-old man from West Belfast in relation to the rioting.<ref name="BBC1"/>
==July riots== A riot broke out on 1 July 2011 in Castlereagh Street and Mountpottinger Road, where the police used water cannons again to stop rioting continuing into the night.{{citation needed|date=July 2011}}
On 9 July, loyalist rioters attacked the PSNI in [[Ballyclare]] after the PSNI removed [[Union Flag|Union]] and paramilitary flags from outside a Catholic church.<ref>[http://www.u.tv/News/Leaders-urge-calm-after-weekend-disorder/2cc20104-b49a-4094-98f2-9f6071f18bf5 Leaders urge calm after weekend disorder], u.tv; accessed 23 October 2015.</ref>
Expected riots broke out on [[Eleventh Night|11 July]] and nationalist rioters attacked the PSNI in the Oldpark and Broadway areas of Belfast. The Royal Victoria Hospital's new £9 million extension was damaged. It is believed shots were fired.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-14116568 11 July riots in Belfast], bbc.co.uk; accessed 23 October 2015.</ref>
More expected rioting broke out the following day in nationalist areas of north and south Belfast following the annual [[Orange Order]] [[Twelfth of July]] parades. Trouble also broke out in [[Derry]], where police claimed people as young as ten were involved. The PSNI were criticised for their handling of the riots.<ref>[http://www.u.tv/utvplayer/video/137910 PSNI criticised for handling of Twelfth of July rioting], u.tv; accessed 23 October 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.psni.police.uk/index/news-archive/news-2011/july-2011/pr_statement_following_disorder_tuesday_12_july_130711.htm PSNI statement following 12 July disorder] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829123339/http://www.psni.police.uk/index/news-archive/news-2011/july-2011/pr_statement_following_disorder_tuesday_12_july_130711.htm |date=29 August 2011 }}, psni.police.uk; accessed 23 October 2015.</ref>
On 15 July, police in [[Portadown]] came under attack with a riot involving around 100 people. Immigrants were forced to flee [[Northern Ireland]] when their home came under attack by loyalists in a Catholic area.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jul/16/east-timor-immigrants-fled-northern-ireland-violence East Timor immigrants flee Northern Ireland violence], guardian.co.uk; accessed 23 October 2015.</ref> The next day, in Corcraine, Portadown, there was further unrest and rioting.<ref>[http://www.psni.police.uk/index/news-archive/news-2011/july-2011/pr_press_facility_supt_murphy_ref_disorder_in_portadown_160711.htm Portadown disorder], psni.police.uk; accessed 23 October 2015.</ref>

page.title: America can't do a damn thing against us

revision.text:
[[File:25th Death Anniversary of Ruhollah Khomeini (13930314 4526610).jpg|thumb|The slogan can be seen in the bottom of [[Ali Khamenei]]'s speech position on 25th Death Anniversary of Ruhollah Khomeini in [[Mausoleum of Ruhollah Khomeini |his mausoleum]], 4 June 2014. ]] '''America can't do a damn thing against us''' ({{lang-fa|آمریکا هیچ غلطی نمی تواند بکند}}) is a slogan originally used by the former [[Supreme Leader of Iran]], [[Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini]] during the [[Iran hostage crisis]],<ref name="Limbert">{{cite book|last=Limbert|first=John W.|title=Negotiating with Iran: Wrestling the Ghosts of History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bihEK0FJxaAC&pg=PA170|year=2009|publisher=US Institute of Peace Press|isbn=978-1-60127-043-6|pages=170–}}</ref> for the first time to assure the Iranians that the [[United States]] would not be able to restore the ousted [[Mohammad Reza Shah Pahlavi|Shah of Iran]] back to the Persian throne. The statement then became an official slogan for the [[Iranian Revolution]] which resulted in the establishment of an [[Islamic Republic]] under Khomeini's rule.<ref name="FP">{{cite news|last1=Clawson|first1=Patrick|title=Iran Can't Agree to a Damn Thing|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2013/02/20/iran-cant-agree-to-a-damn-thing/|accessdate=30 January 2016|work=Foreign Policy|date=20 February 2013}}</ref>
== Application == Responding to Iran's request for extradition of the [[Shah of Iran]] [[Muhammad Reza Pahlavi]], the [[President of the United States]], [[Jimmy Carter]], provided for the Shah's travel plans to [[Panama]] with the deliberate intention of eliminating the possibility of the extradition in exchange for hostages who were held by the revolutionary Iran for 444 days (November 4, 1979, to January 20, 1981) after a group of Iranian revolutionary students affiliated with [[Muslim Student Followers of the Imam's Line]] broke into and entered the [[Embassy of the United States, Tehran|Embassy of the United States of America]] in [[Tehran]], and took its diplomatic staff hostage, in contravention of international law, in response to the US providing political asylum for the Shah.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Chalk|first1=Peter|title=Encyclopedia of Terrorism (2 volume set)|date=2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0313308956|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=czK7lIU7m1oC&pg=PT1000&lpg=PT1000&dq=were+held+hostage+for+444+days+November+4,+1979,+to+January+20,+1981)+after+a+group+of+Iranian+students+belonging+to+the+Muslim+Student+Followers+of+the+Imam%27s+Line+who+supported+the+Iranian+Revolution,+took+over+the+U.S.+Embassy+in+Tehran&source=bl&ots=wEabWf9qJF&sig=qD8t3TRMGae2xvupEVgvRtqG1RA&hl=fa&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPwqa40fbKAhUDGZoKHbSPChMQ6AEIOjAF#v=onepage&q=were%20held%20hostage%20for%20444%20days%20(November%204%2C%201979%2C%20to%20January%2020%2C%201981)%20after%20a%20group%20of%20Iranian%20students%20belonging%20to%20the%20Muslim%20Student%20Followers%20of%20the%20Imam's%20Line%20who%20supported%20the%20Iranian%20Revolution%2C%20took%20over%20the%20U.S.%20Embassy%20in%20Tehran&f=false}}</ref><ref name= "keyhan">{{cite news | url=http://www.magiran.com/ppdf/nppdf/2827/p02827211700061.pdf | title=Firm responses to void threats - Imam Khomeini said: America can't do a damn thing against us. | work=Kayhan | date=30 September 2015 | accessdate=1 February 2016}}</ref> A week after the incident, the sheets and finances of Iran were confiscated by US{{clarify|date=February 2016}}. Yet, in spite of what were deemed by Iran to be international threats, there was still the possibility of holding trials for alleged American spies, and the reaction of Ayatollah Khomeini against the threat of Carter{{clarify|date=February 2016}} published regularly by international media, was the slogan "America can't do a damn thing against us."<ref name="keyhan" />
The slogan appeared on many walls and banners such as a billboard along the Iran-Iraq border, a banner which was hung in front of the [[Iran–U.S. RQ-170 incident|U.S captured RQ-170 drone]] and a banner above which [[Ali Khamenei]] was speaking at an event commemorating the 25th anniversary Khamenei.{{clarify|date=February 2016}}<ref name="Limbert"/><ref name="FP"/><ref name="Daily Mail">{{cite news|last1=Pow|first1=Helen|title='America cannot do a damn thing': Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei taunts President Obama claiming he doesn't have the guts for a military attack|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2649625/America-damn-thing-Irans-supreme-leader-Ayatollah-Ali-Khamenei-claims-President-Obama-doesnt-guts-military-attack-speech.html|accessdate=30 January 2016|work=Daily Mail}}</ref>
The slogan was also used by Khamenei, Khomeini's successor, while speaking to teachers on Teacher's Day in Iran,<ref name="TOI">{{cite news|last1=Winer|first1=Stuart|title=Khamenei to US: Your military ‘can't do a damn thing' to us|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/iran-leader-puts-kibosh-on-talks-under-us-threat-of-attack/|accessdate=30 January 2016|work=Times of Israel}}</ref> and on other several occasions.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Staff|title=America can't do a damn thing|language=fa|url=http://farsi.khamenei.ir/audio-content?id=29938|website=KHAMENEI.IR|accessdate=31 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Karami|first1=Arash|title=Khamenei: Iran rejected US offer to cooperate against IS|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/09/iran-rejects-us-offer-cooperate-is.html|accessdate=31 January 2016|work=Al-Monitor}}</ref> It was also used by some other Iranian officials.<ref>{{cite news|title=Iran: Obama 'can't do a damn thing'|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/36212348/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/t/iran-obama-cant-do-damn-thing/|accessdate=31 January 2016|work=NBC news|agency=Associated Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Staff|title=Ahmadinejad: U.S. Can't Do "Damn Thing" on Nukes|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ahmadinejad-us-cant-do-damn-thing-on-nukes/|accessdate=31 January 2016|work=CBS News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Staff|title=Only Iran is confronting Islamic State, paramilitary chief says|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/mideast-crisis-iraq-iran-idUSL5N0YG0MK20150525?rpc=401|accessdate=31 January 2016|work=Reuters}}</ref>

'''Baugrygr''' or '''Ringkvinna''' was the term for an unmarried woman who had inherited the position of head of the family, usually from her father or brother, with all the tasks and rights associated with the position. The position existed in [[Scandinavia]] during the [[Viking era]] and into the [[middle ages]].
Ringkvinna is primarily mentioned in the [[Iceland]]ic [[Grágás]] and the Norwegian [[Frostathing Law|Frostating]] laws and [[Gulating]] laws, in which it is phrased in much the same way. Unmarried women in general, referred to as ''maer'' and ''mey'', were secure in their rights of independence: at the age of 20, a woman reached the right of legal majority and had the right to decide about her own place of residence and stand by herself in all juridical senses before the law.These same rights applied to widows.<ref>Borgström Eva {{sv icon}}: Makalösa kvinnor: könsöverskridare i myt och verklighet (Marvelous women : genderbenders in myth and reality) Alfabeta/Anamma, Stockholm 2002. {{ISBN|91-501-0191-9}}</ref> The one exception to her independence was the right to choose a marriage partner, which was a matter for the whole family.<ref>Borgström Eva{{sv icon}}: Makalösa kvinnor: könsöverskridare i myt och verklighet (Marvelous women : genderbenders in myth and reality) Alfabeta/Anamma, Stockholm 2002. {{ISBN|91-501-0191-9}} (inb.). Libris 8707902.</ref>
In the absence of male relatives, an unmarried woman with no son could inherit the position as head of the family from a deceased father or brother. Women with such status were referred to as ringkvinna. She exercised all the rights afforded to the head of a family clan until she married at which time her rights were transferred to her husband. The right to inherit in itself applied to both the paternal aunt, paternal niece and paternal granddaughter of the deceased, who were all named as ''odalkvinna'', but the right to inherit the position of head of the family was a right which could only be inherited by the daughter or the sister of a dead man.<ref>Borgström Eva{{sv icon}}: Makalösa kvinnor: könsöverskridare i myt och verklighet (Marvelous women : genderbenders in myth and reality) Alfabeta/Anamma, Stockholm 2002. {{ISBN|91-501-0191-9}}</ref>
The ringkvinna had the specific support of the law to perform all the tasks normally performed by a head of the family, such as, the right to demand and receive fines for the slaughter of a family member.<ref>Borgström Eva{{sv icon}}: Makalösa kvinnor: könsöverskridare i myt och verklighet (Marvelous women : genderbenders in myth and reality) Alfabeta/Anamma, Stockholm 2002. {{ISBN|91-501-0191-9}} (inb.). Libris 8707902.</ref> If she married, however, these rights were passed on to her spouse. These rights were preserved also after [[Christianization]] although they seem to have disappeared in the late 13th century, at which time they are no longer mentioned in any law texts.<ref>Borgström Eva{{sv icon}}: Makalösa kvinnor: könsöverskridare i myt och verklighet (Marvelous women : genderbenders in myth and reality) Alfabeta/Anamma, Stockholm 2002. {{ISBN|91-501-0191-9}} (inb.). Libris 8707902.</ref>

{{small|(not legal successor)}} |position=[[Syncretic politics|Syncretic]] |colours={{color box|#000000|border=darkgray}} [[Black]] {{color box|#FF0000|border=darkgray}} [[Red]] |flag= }} The '''Combat League of Revolutionary National Socialists''' ([[German language|German]]: ''Kampfgemeinschaft Revolutionärer Nationalsozialisten'', '''KGRNS'''), more commonly known as the '''Black Front''' ({{lang-de|Schwarze Front}}), was a political group formed by [[Otto Strasser]] after his expulsion from the [[Nazi Party]] (NSDAP) in 1930.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nT-psA9fj_AC&pg=PA248&dq=black+front+strasser&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiA5av0hYTTAhWkDsAKHQwwClIQ6AEILTAD#v=onepage&q=black%20front%20strasser&f=false|title=Who's Who in Nazi Germany|last=Wistrich|first=Robert S.|date=4 July 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136413810|pages=248}} Strasser believed the original [[anti-capitalist]] nature of the [[NSDAP]] had been betrayed by [[Adolf Hitler]]. The Black Front was composed of former radical members of the NSDAP, who intended to cause a split in the main party. Strasser's organisation published a newspaper, ''The German Revolution''. The Black Front adopted the crossed hammer and sword symbol which is still used by several [[Strasserism|Strasserite]] groupings today. The organisation was unable to oppose the NSDAP effectively and Hitler’s rise to power proved to be the final straw. Strasser spent the years of the [[Third Reich]] in exile, first in [[First Czechoslovak Republic|Czechoslovakia]] and later in [[Canada]]. The social fascist wing of the NSDAP itself was eradicated in 1934 during the [[Night of the Long Knives]] in which [[Gregor Strasser]], Otto's elder brother, was killed. == See also == * [[National Bolshevik Party]] * [[Socialist Reich Party]] * [[Strasserism]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{NSDAP}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1930 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:1934 disestablishments in Germany]] [[Category:Fascism]] [[Category:German nationalist organizations]] [[Category:German resistance to Nazism]] [[Category:Organizations disestablished in 1934]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1930]] [[Category:Political organisations in Germany]] [[Category:Third Position]] {{Germany-hist-stub}} {{Germany-party-stub}}

{{primary sources|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox political party |name=Association "Borotba" |native_name=Об'єднання "Боротьба" |logo= |colorcode= darkred |leader=Serhiy Kirichuk |founded={{start date|2011|05|01}} |headquarters=[[Odessa]] |ideology=[[Communism]]
[[Marxism–Leninism]]
[[Anti-Maidan]] |position=[[Far-left politics|Far-left]] |colours= |flag=Флаг объединения «Боротьба».svg |website={{Official URL}} |country=Ukraine}} The '''Association “Struggle”''' ({{lang-uk|Об'єднання "Боротьба" '''Ob'yednannia “Boroťba”'''}}; {{lang-ru|Объединение “Боротьба”}}) is a [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]] organization operating in [[Odessa]] and [[Kharkiv]], [[Kiev|Kyiv]], and [[Dnipro|Dnipropetrovsk]] in [[Ukraine]]. ==Draft Manifesto== The Draft Manifesto of the Organization declares:
Union “Borotba” stands for Revolutionary Marxism, and its most important task – to extend Left ideology implementing Marxist methodology in the political discourse of Ukraine.
The Manifest also states that the organization will support principles of [[anti-capitalism]], [[Proletarian internationalism|internationalism]], [[anti-fascism]], [[political radicalism]] and [[gender equality]].{{cite web|url=http://borotba.su/ideology.html|title=Ideology|publisher=|accessdate=29 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150304042113/http://www.borotba.su/ideology.html|archivedate=4 March 2015|df=}} ==History== {{refimprove section|date=May 2014}} Taking the name of oppositional political party in Soviet Ukraine, from 1920 until 1925, which had merged with the [[Ukrainian Communist Party]] in 1920,[https://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1920/feb/06b.htm#fwV42E9196 Draft Resolution on the Ukrainian Borotbist Party] 6 February 1920 Borotba has been described as part of the emerging heterogeneous New Left in Ukraine.Volodymyr Ishchenko (NaUKMA, Department of Sociology). ''[https://www.academia.edu/5570211/Ukrainian_New_Left_and_Grassroots_Social_Protests_A_Thorny_Way_to_Hegemony Ukrainian New Left and Grassroots Social Protests: A Thorny Way to Hegemony]'', presented at the "Making the World Working Class" Tenth Annual [[Historical Materialism (journal)]] conference, London, 7–10 November 2013. Its leader is the Russian, Victor Shapinov, formerly active in [[Russian Communist Workers Party]] before moving to Ukraine in 2005.Greg Butterfield "[http://www.workers.org/articles/2014/10/22/left-ukraine-origins-borotba/ The left in Ukraine and the origins of Borotba] ''Workers World'' 22 October 2014 The association was established in May 2011 by former members of the "Organization of Marxists" (a [[Marxism–Leninism|Marxist-Leninist]] group formed in 2007International Council of Friendship and Solidarity with Soviet People "[http://www.northstarcompass.org/nsc0707/marxists.htm "Organization of Marxists" Is Born in Ukraine]" ''North Star Compass'' July/August 2007, Vol. 15, No. 11-1), the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] (KPU) and its [[Komsomol of Ukraine|youth wing]] the "Leninist Communist Youth Union of Ukraine, the "All-Ukrainian Union of Workers", the "Youth Association Che Guevara" and the "Youth against capitalism" movement, with some individual leftist activists also joining. The founding congress was attended by delegates from across Ukraine. International guests from [[Sweden]] and [[Russia]] were also present.[http://www.borotba.su/history.html History of the organization] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214042234/http://www.borotba.su/history.html|date=December 14, 2014}}, ''Official site of the "Borotba" Association'', accessed on 15 May 2014. Borotba has cooperated with and received support from [[Germany]]'s [[The Left (Germany)|Die Linke]]{{r|DLB}} and the Swedish [[Left Party (Sweden)|Left Party]]'s VIF aid organization. It also cooperates with the [[Left Front (Russia)|Left Front]], a [[Russia]]n [[Opposition to Vladimir Putin in Russia|opposition]] group."Our partner in Russia is the Left Front, many of their activists are in prisons now and we are showing our solidarity with them" http://www.andrej-hunko.de/7-beitrag/2120-they-hate-us-because-we-are-communists{{r|Afton150311}} ==Activities== When the [[Euromaidan]] movement started in 2013, Borotba were critical of it from the outset. Some members of Borotba, including Dennis Levine, attempted to recruit protesters to the Confederation of Independent Trade Unions of Ukraine to fight against increased public transport costs in Kiev. According to Svetlana Tsiberganova, they were attacked by the far-right.http://www.liva.com.ua/not-my-war.html Not My War, by Svetlana Tsiberganova Borotba's analysis of the authorities that replaced former President [[Viktor Yanukovych]] and the [[second Azarov government]] after the [[2014 Ukrainian revolution]] on 22 February 2014 is that [[Far-right politics|far-right]] [[Ukrainian nationalism|nationalists]] received too much power and control over important ministries and agencies including defense, anti-corruption and national security, education, agriculture and the environment, as well as the office of the [[Prosecutor General of Ukraine]].Roger Annis. [http://truth-out.org/opinion/item/23656-popular-rebellion-deepens-in-eastern-and-southern-ukraine-as-nato-and-rightist-government-in-kiev-step-up-attacks "Popular Rebellion Deepens in Eastern and Southern Ukraine as NATO and the Kiev Government Step Up Attacks"], truth-out.org (13 May 2014). Retrieved 24-08-2014. Borotba has condemned what they considered a "Western-backed"Bill Van Auken, [http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2014/04/16/swuk-a16.html "The International Socialist Organization and the Ukraine crisis"], World Socialist Web Site (16 April 2014). Retrieved 24-08-2014. and "[[Fascism|fascist]]" February 2014 coup in [[Kiev]] and called for a [[Revolutionary socialism|socialist revolution]] in Ukraine against the government of "[[Ultranationalism|ultra-nationalists]] and [[Nazism|Nazis]]".[http://borotba.su/communique_4_of_the_borotba_union_and_centre_of_anti-fascist_resistance1.html The government of ultraliberals and Nazis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214041301/http://borotba.su/communique_4_of_the_borotba_union_and_centre_of_anti-fascist_resistance1.html|date=December 14, 2014}}, ''Official site of the Borotba Association'', accessed on 15 May 2014. Borotba's members took an active role in political events in [[Kharkiv]] in March 2014.{{ru icon}} Григорий Пырлик. [http://www.mediaport.ua/borotba-za-yugo-vostok-kto-skolko-zachem «Боротьба» за Юго-Восток. Кто, сколько, зачем], ''Mediaport'', 22 March 2014. On March 15, Borotba, the "People’s Unity" and other groups called a public meeting in Kharkiv. Borotba joined [[Anti-Maidan]] protesters in storming the [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine#Kharkiv Oblast|regional administration building]],{{r|KharkivRAB}} which at that time was occupied by pro-Maidan activists, and their members are accused by other Ukrainian left organisations for taking part in the beating of pro-Maidan activists, including anarchists and the well-known Ukrainian author [[Serhiy Zhadan]].{{r|avtonomia.net}} Borotba justified their action by calling the occupants members of [[Right Sector]].Facenews: "Police abandoned administration building, it is guarded only by Right Sector" http://www.facenews.ua/news/2014/190937/[http://borotba.su/kommyunike_n6_obedineniya_borotba_i_czentra_antifashistskogo_soprotivleniya.html Borotba during the protests in the Southeast] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214043511/http://borotba.su/kommyunike_n6_obedineniya_borotba_i_czentra_antifashistskogo_soprotivleniya.html|date=December 14, 2014}} Borotba.org: Kommunique Nr.6, accessed 4 July 2014 (Russian) On April 15, and May 8, 2014, Borotba's office in Kharkiv was raided by police.{{ru icon}} [http://dozor.kharkov.ua/news/politics/1150499.html Маски-шоу в офисе партии «Боротьба» в центре Харькова], ''Dozor.kharkov.ua'', 21 June 2014 In Kharkiv, Borotba activists claim to have printed 100,000 leaflets and 10,000 posters persuading the voters to boycott the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2014|presidential election in May 2014]], since they considered it unrepresentative, radical rightist, and illegitimate.[http://links.org.au/node/3866 Ukraine: 'Socialist prospects in south-eastern Ukraine'], ''Links International Journal of Socialist Renewal'', May 25, 2014. On [[May Day]], Borotba members staged a rally in Kovalska Street in [[Odessa]].[https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/5360f7e3e4b02d8b94bc7b0e/955978 May Day rally of 'Borotba' union in Odessa], ''GuardianWitness''. Later in May, Borotba joined other [[Anti-Maidan]] parties (Yury Apukhtin's "Southeast" movement, the [[Progressive Socialist Party of Ukraine]] and the KPU) in rallying against the presidential elections.{{r|May2014rally}} The leader of the Odessan regional organisation of Borotba, Aleksey Albu, fled to [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russian-annexed]] [[Crimea]], where he founded a "Committee for the Liberation of Odessa" on 24 May 2014 together with representatives of the Russian nationalist party [[Rodina (political party)|Rodina]] and of the organization "Slavic Unity".{{r|ReferenceA}}{{r|ipress.ua}} On September 12, a Borotba activist was arrested in Odessa by the Internal Security Service (SBU), under the accusation of terrorism.Left wing activists arrested and tortured in Odessa http://ukraineantifascistsolidarity.wordpress.com/2014/09/15/left-wing-activists-arrested-and-tortured-in-odessa/ ==Criticism== On March 3, 2014, several left and [[Anarchism|anarchist]] organizations in Ukraine, including the Autonomous Workers Union, the [[Direct Action (trade union)|"Direct Action" Independent Student Union]] and the Left Opposition socialist organization, criticized Borotba for alleged cooperation with conservative pro-Russian groups in Ukraine and allegedly spreading "overt lies and fact manipulations". In a rebuttal, Borotba rejected the accusations as "hypocritical" and "irrelevant".{{r|Bor-SC}} Borotba states that it has regularly criticized Russian authorities and organized in solidarity with left-wing Russian organizations that met with repression from the Russian authorities.{{cite web|url=http://borotba.su/borotba-solidarna-s-protestami-v-rossii-video.html|title=БОРОТЬБА солидарна с протестами в России (+ВИДЕО)|publisher=|accessdate=29 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214051232/http://borotba.su/borotba-solidarna-s-protestami-v-rossii-video.html|archivedate=14 December 2014|df=}} After the circulation of these allegations, the regional coordination office of the German federal [[The Left (Germany)|Die Linke]] party distanced itself from Borotba and its founding member Serhei Kirichuk, who is currently living in German exile.[http://www.die-linke-hamburg.de/termine/detail/artikel/vom-maidan-in-den-buergerkrieg.html Vom Maidan in den Bürgerkrieg?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140722151231/http://www.die-linke-hamburg.de/termine/detail/artikel/vom-maidan-in-den-buergerkrieg.html# |date=2014-07-22 }} From Maidan to civil war? (German) DIE LINKE Landesverband Hamburg, accessed 4 July 2014 Die Linke cancelled several events with Kirichuk, such as a panel discussion in Hamburg on the 2 July 2014 and in Kiel 3 July 2014.[http://www.kieler-friedensarbeit.de/bototba.htm Bündnis Friede, Freiheit, Brot] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714143724/http://www.kieler-friedensarbeit.de/bototba.htm# |date=2014-07-14 }} Kieler Friedensarbeit, accessed 4 July 2014 A book presentation which Kirichuk had helped to organise was also cancelled due to the author's ties to Russian neo-Nazi groups such as [[Russian National Unity]] and the anti-immigrant [[Movement Against Illegal Immigration|DPNI]].{{r|Nihilist}} Kirichuk responded to many of the accusations levelled against the organisation, especially with regard to their support for separatists in the South and East of Ukraine, in an interview with [[Andrej Hunko]] of Die Linke.[http://www.andrej-hunko.de/7-beitrag/2120-they-hate-us-because-we-are-communists "They hate us because we are communists"], Interview with Sergei Kirichuk by Andrej Hunko (09.07.2014). Retrieved 24-08-2014. ==See also== *[[Antifascist Committee of Ukraine]] *[[Communist Party of the Donetsk People's Republic]] *[[Communist Party of Ukraine]] *[[Progressive Socialist Party of Ukraine]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= [http://borotba.su/kommyunike_n6_obedineniya_borotba_i_czentra_antifashistskogo_soprotivleniya.html Borotba during the protests in the Southeast] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214043511/http://borotba.su/kommyunike_n6_obedineniya_borotba_i_czentra_antifashistskogo_soprotivleniya.html|date=December 14, 2014}} Borotba.org: Kommunique Nr.6, accessed 4 July 2014 (Russian). Russian text: Координатор харьквоской «Боротьбы» Денис Зайцев: «Сегодня, ударная группа харьковской «Боротьбы», вместе с другими антинационалистическими силами взяли штурмом областную госадминистрацию. Translated: Coordinator of Kharkiw group of Borot'ba, Denis Zajcev: "''Today the hit group of the Kharkiw Borot'ba took over the regional administration together with anti-nationalist groups''" [http://avtonomia.net/2014/03/03/statement-left-anarchist-organizations-borotba-organization/ Statement of left and anarchist organizations about Borotba organization], ''Official site of Autonomous Workers' Union'', March 3, 2014, accessed on 20 May 2014. {{ru icon}} [http://nihilist.li/2014/06/19/ot-melkih-moshennikov-do-ubijts-ocherk-o-politicheskoj-e-volyutsii-stalinistov-na-primere-organizatsii-borot-ba/ От мелких мошенников до убийц. Очерк о политической эволюции сталинистов на примере организации Боротьба] Nihilist.li: From petty criminals to murders. Essay on the political evolution of the stalinists at the example of the organization Borot'ba. [http://indymedia.co.uk/en/2014/09/517921.html English translation] [http://voiceofrussia.com/news/2014_05_18/Rally-in-Ukraines-Kharkov-calls-for-boycotting-presidential-elections-promises-referendum-5911/ Rally in Ukraine's Kharkov calls for boycotting presidential elections, promises referendum]; "[http://en.itar-tass.com/world/732062 East Ukraine’s Kharkov region to hold independence referendum - movement “Southeast”]" Tass 18 May 2014. Apukhin, the leader of the “Great Russia” NGO, is a pro-Putin activist ("[http://nahnews.com.ua/14685-yuri-apukhtin-we-have-nothing-to-do-with-the-european-civilization-we-are-completely-different/ Yuri Apukhtin: “We have nothing to do with the European civilization. We are completely different.”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141031183729/http://nahnews.com.ua/14685-yuri-apukhtin-we-have-nothing-to-do-with-the-european-civilization-we-are-completely-different/|date=October 31, 2014}}" nahnews.com.ua 20 December 2013 {{ru icon}} [http://www.borotba.su/v_kryimu_obyavili_o_sozdanii_komiteta_osvobozhdeniya_odessyi.html "On Crimea, a committee for the liberation of Odessa was founded] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214043332/http://www.borotba.su/v_kryimu_obyavili_o_sozdanii_komiteta_osvobozhdeniya_odessyi.html|date=December 14, 2014}} Website of Borot'ba", accessed 11 July 2014 {{ru icon}} [http://ipress.ua/ru/news/deputatibegletsi_formyruyut_v_krimu_komytet_osvobozhdenyya_odessi_65896.html Representatives on the run founded a "Committee for the Liberation of Odessa" on Crimea.] '''Quote''': "The Organisation was created by a member of the city council of the party "Rodina" (homeland), Aleksandr Vasilev, a member of the regional council, leader of the regional organisation of Bor'ba (Russian name for Borot'ba) Aleksey Albu and the leader of the "Odessian Squad" Dmitry Odinov, who at the same time is member of the extreme right wing 'Slavic Union'." ipress.ua (22 May 2014). Accessed 11 July 2014. Statement of the union ‘Borotba’ over recent smear campaign against anti-fascists in Ukraine: "We are not part of the movement that takes sides according to orders given from NGOs. We are not part of the movement that tries to hide left symbolic and social slogans in current situation. We are not part of the movement that buys into nationalist and patriotic hysteria spreading all over the country. We are not part of the movement that tries to defend the coup on behalf of Nazis, oligarchs and IMF. We are not part of the movement that tries to diminish the role of Nazis in Euromaidan or even whitewash their image when even mainstream western media show far-right paramilitaries roaming over the streets." http://borotba.su/statement_of_the_union_borotba_over_recent_smear_campaign_against_anti-fascists_in_ukraine.html{{dead link|date=November 2016|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}} {{cite web|url=http://www.dielinke-bremen.de/nc/politik/aktuell/detail/browse/1/zurueck/bremennews/artikel/authentische-informationen-und-einschaetzungen-aus-der-ukraine-1/|title=DIE LINKE in Bremen: Authentische Informationen und Einschätzungen aus der Ukraine|publisher=|accessdate=29 December 2014}} {{cite news|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article20447581.ab|title=AFTONBLADET AVSLÖJAR: V gav bistånd till pro-ryssar|first=Lisa|last=Röstlund|first2=Egor|last2=Putilov|work=[[Aftonbladet]]|date=11 March 2015}}}} ==External links== *{{Official URL}} *[https://www.academia.edu/20445056/The_Ukrainian_Left_during_and_after_the_Maidan_Protests Volodymyr Ishchenko. {{More citations needed|date=January 2009}} {{Infobox historic site | name = Canadian Forces Station Carp | native_name = | native_language = | other_name = | etymology = | image = Diefenbunker.JPG | caption = Carp Diefenbunker gate and entrance | alt = | locmapin = | coordinates = {{coord|45|21|06|N|76|02|50|W|region:CA-ON_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], Canada | area = | elevation = | founded = 1962 | founder = Diefenbunker Development Group | built = 1959–1961 | original_use = [[Emergency Government Headquarters]] | current_use = Museum | architect = Foundation Corporation of Canada, L. Col. Ed Churchill | architecture = | governing_body = Diefenbunker, Canada's Cold War Museum | owner = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | website = [http://www.diefenbunker.ca Diefenbunker: Canada's Cold War Museum] | designation1 = National Historic Site of Canada | designation1_offname = Diefenbunker / Central Emergency Government Headquarters National Historic Site of Canada | designation1_date = 1994 | designation1_number = | designation2 = | designation2_offname = | designation2_date = | designation2_number = }} '''Canadian Forces Station Carp''' (also '''CFS Carp''' and commonly known as '''The Diefenbunker''') is a former [[Canada|Canadian]] military facility located in the rural farming community of [[Carp, Ontario|Carp]], [[Ontario]], approximately {{Convert|30|km|abbr=on}} west of [[downtown Ottawa]].
CFS Carp was decommissioned in 1994. It was not until 1998 that it was reopened as a museum and designated a [[National Historic Sites of Canada|National Historic Site of Canada]].<ref>[http://www.pc.gc.ca/apps/lhn-nhs/det_E.asp?oqSID=0834&oqeName=Diefenbunker+%2F+Central+Emergency+Government+Headquarters&oqfName=Diefenbunker+%2F+si%E8ge+central+du+gouvernement+d%27%27urgence Diefenbunker / Central Emergency Government Headquarters ], Directory of Designations of National Historic Significance of Canada</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.historicplaces.ca/en/rep-reg/place-lieu.aspx?id=4169 | title = Diefenbunker / Central Emergency Government Headquarters National Historic Site of Canada | accessdate = 2013-06-02 | quote = Formally Recognized: 1994/06/05}}</ref> Currently, the facility operates as a museum and is open year-round for tours.<ref name="diefenbunker.ca">In [http://diefenbunker.ca/en_index.shtml ''Diefenbunker, Canada's Cold War Museum''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130430041020/http://www.diefenbunker.ca/en_index.shtml |date=2013-04-30 }} Retrieved April 15, 2013.</ref><ref name="Ottawa Museums">[http://www.ottawamuseums.com/diefenbunker.aspx Diefenbunker, Canada's Cold War Museum] in ''Ottawa Museums''. Retrieved March 15, 2013.</ref>
==History== In 1958, at the height of the [[Cold War]] and the infancy of the [[intercontinental ballistic missile]] (ICBM) threat, Prime Minister [[John Diefenbaker]] authorized the creation of close to 50 [[Emergency Government Headquarters]] (nicknamed "Diefenbunkers" by opposition parties<ref name="Forces">{{cite news|url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/commun/ml-fe/article-eng.asp?id=6587|title=The Diefenbunker: Echoes from our past, or back to the future?|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130629072313/http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/commun/ml-fe/article-eng.asp?id=6587|archivedate=June 29, 2013|date=November 17, 2010|work=The Maple Leaf|last=Thermidor|first=Emeline}}</ref>) across Canada. These shelters were part of what came to be known as the [[Continuity of Government]] plan,<ref name="Ottawa Museums"/><ref name="diefenbunker.ca history">[http://diefenbunker.ca/pages/museum_history/index.shtml Diefenbunker, Canada's Cold War Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130329213921/http://diefenbunker.ca/pages/museum_history/index.shtml |date=2013-03-29 }}. Retrieved March 15, 2013.</ref> which was meant to protect various members of government in the event of a nuclear attack.<ref name="Forces"/>
The original site, some {{convert|9.7|km|abbr=on}} east of [[Almonte, Ontario|Almonte]] ({{Coord|45|15|06.66|N|076|19|31.05|W|region:CA-ON_type:landmark|name=Almonte, Ontario}}) was abandoned when ground water proved impossible to remove. An abandoned gravel pit outside Carp was selected instead, construction began in 1959 and was completed by 1962.<ref name="Forces"/>
The Carp shelter would be the largest of such facilities (over {{Convert|9,300|m2|abbr=on}}<ref name="Ottawa Museums"/>) and the only one in the immediate Ottawa area. The underground 4-storey bunker required 32,000 tonnes of concrete and 5,000 tonnes of steel. The structure was capable of withstanding a nuclear blast up to 5 megatons from {{convert|1.8|km|abbr=on}} away. It had massive blast doors at the surface, as well as extensive air filters to prevent radiation infiltration.<ref name="Forces"/> Although supposedly effective against surface nuclear detonations, the facility was later found to be vulnerable to conventional [[Bunker buster]] bombs developed after its construction, as these bombs had time delay fuses that would detonate after they had penetrated deeply enough underground.<ref name="Forces"/>
[[File:Blast tunnel entrance at CFS Carp.jpg|thumb|The blast tunnel entrance. The doors to the actual bunker are perpendicular to this tunnel which reduces the effects of a nuclear shock wave.]]
Underground storage was built for food, fuel, fresh water, and other supplies. The bunker was built to accommodate 565 people for up to one month without receiving additional supplies from the outside.<ref name="Forces"/> It included an emergency broadcast studio for the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]<ref name="Forces"/> and a vault on the lowest level to hold the gold reserves of the [[Bank of Canada]].
These facilities were administered by the [[Royal Canadian Corps of Signals]] (later the [[Communications and Electronics Branch]]). A decentralized transmitter site, the [[CFS Carp Richardson Detachment|Richardson Detachment]], with numerous transmitter antenna was located further to the west near Perth Ontario that was supported from a 2-storey underground facility of similar construction to the Carp facility but much smaller. Two radio receiving facilities, the [[CFS Carp Almonte Detachment]] and [[CFS Carp Dunrobin Detachment]], with a complete receiving antenna arrays were built in the region but all buildings were above ground.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rcsigs.ca/ViewUnit/59/ | title = CFS Carp - Units | accessdate = 2013-06-02 | quote = CFS Carp was to provide the administration, security and housekeeping services needed to maintain a constant state of operational readiness for all sites under its command; most importantly, the communication facilities at Carp, Richardson, Almonte and Dunrobin | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131023061701/http://www.rcsigs.ca/ViewUnit/59/ | archivedate = 2013-10-23 | df = }}</ref>
[[File:Prime Minister's quarters at CFS Carp.jpg|thumb|A re-creation of the very limited quarters provided for the [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]]. Military restrictions prohibited the Prime Minister from being accompanied by his wife and for this reason [[John Diefenbaker]] is rumoured to have refused to ever use the facility.<ref name="ar1">[https://archive.is/20130118161038/http://www.canada.com/saskatoonstarphoenix/news/story.html?id=7934bd18-0498-4660-a2a1-12d6c88907b0&k=75122 Catch some Cold War cinema at The Diefenbunker — Canada’s most unusual movie theatre]</ref>]]
==Diefenbunker, Canada's Cold War Museum== [[File:Main conference room inside Diefenbunker.jpg|thumb|left|The main conference room inside the Diefenbunker to provide continuity of Canada's government activities that were legal and constitutional in case of a nuclear attack.<ref>{{cite web|last=Peters|first=Dave|title=CD - The Continuity of Government Program - Principles|url=http://diefenbunker.ca/pages/papers_canada_s_emergency_government_bunkers/cd_the_continuity_of_government_program_-_principles_printer.shtml|publisher=The Diefenbunker, Canada's Cold War Museum|accessdate=1 November 2013|date=January 2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105020817/http://diefenbunker.ca/pages/papers_canada_s_emergency_government_bunkers/cd_the_continuity_of_government_program_-_principles_printer.shtml|archivedate=5 November 2013}}</ref>]] CFS Carp was decommissioned in 1994<ref name="Then and Now">Peters, Dave (April 2011). [http://www.mysteriesofcanada.com/Military/diefenbunker.htm "The 'Diefenbunker': Then and Now"] in ''Mysteries of Canada.'' Retrieved March 15, 2013.</ref> following the reduction in the [[Intercontinental Ballistic Missile|ICBM]] threat.
From 1959 to 1994, the site was owned and operated by the Government of Canada, Department of National Defence.<ref name="diefenbunker.ca history"/> After the local municipality took control of the facility in 1994, the community took a great interest in the bunker, requesting access to public tours of the facility.<ref name="diefenbunker.ca history"/> The local municipality took control of the facility and a group of local volunteers, recognizing the heritage and tourism value of the Carp Diefenbunker, undertook to open the facility as a cold war museum and conduct public tours. It was purchased by the Diefenbunker Development Group in 1998, and officially opened as a museum. The name of the facility was changed to the Diefenbunker, Canada's Cold War Museum<ref name="diefenbunker.ca"/> shortly thereafter. It is currently open year-round for public tours.<ref name="Ottawa Museums"/><ref name="Forces"/>
Many areas of the bunker, including the PM's Suite, the Emergency Government Situation Centre, the CBC Emergency Broadcasting Studio, the Military Federal Warning Centre, the External Affairs Ministerial Office, the Public Works Minister's Office and the Bank of Canada Vault, are being restored to their operational condition. The rest of the 358 rooms have been converted to exhibits of the Cold War era.<ref name="Then and Now"/>
===Growth=== Upon its opening in 1998, the museum was run completely by volunteers. However, the 5,000 visitors received that year was too much to be handled solely by volunteers.<ref name="diefenbunker.ca history"/>
In 1999, the museum's second year of operation, a curator was hired along with some students. The museum's visitation doubled to 10,000 people that year.<ref name="diefenbunker.ca history"/>
The museum continued to grow into the 2000s. Close to 15,000 visitors passed through the Diefenbunker in 2000. Additional part-time staff was hired throughout the year to keep up with museum maintenance and upkeep. As of 2008, the Diefenbunker averages approximately 25,000 visitors each year. Four full-time staff, nine part-time staff and numerous volunteers work to keep the museum running smoothly. In 2012, the museum had 45,280 visitors. This was one of the highest increases in attendance other than the opening year of the Bunker.<ref name="diefenbunker.ca history"/>
The mandate of Diefenbunker, Canada's Cold War museum is "to increase throughout Canada and the world, interest in and a critical understanding of the Cold War, by preserving the Diefenbunker as a national historic site, and operating a Cold War Museum.<ref name="diefenbunker.ca About">[http://diefenbunker.ca/pages/about_the_diefenbunker/index.shtml About the Diefenbunker] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130304192048/http://diefenbunker.ca/pages/about_the_diefenbunker/index.shtml |date=2013-03-04 }} in ''Diefenbunker, Canada's Cold War Museum''. Retrieved March 15, 2013.</ref>
==Collections and research== The Diefenbunker houses a collection of Cold War artefacts, an archive and a library, all of which are made available to researchers upon request, and to the general public through the exhibitions.<ref>[http://diefenbunker.ca/pages/collections_research/index.shtml Collections and Research] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130325082314/http://diefenbunker.ca/pages/collections_research/index.shtml |date=2013-03-25 }} in ''Diefenbunker, Canada's Cold War Museum.'' Retrieved March 15, 2013.</ref>
==Funding== The Diefenbunker: Canada's Cold War museum is a not-for-profit, charitable museum.<ref name="diefenbunker.ca About"/> It is funded privately;<ref name="diefenbunker.ca About"/> the main source of revenue for the museum comes from admission sales (approximately 75% of total revenue<ref name="Then and Now"/>). The Diefenbunker actively applies for private, municipal, provincial and federal grants. The museum also relies on the generous support of the community through donations and sponsorship.<ref name="Then and Now"/>
==Additional services== The Diefenbunker offers additional services on top of public tours. The museum has space available to rent both for events and storage.<ref name="Forces"/> The decommissioned bunker has been used as a movie set on several occasions, including for ''[[The Sum of All Fears (film)|The Sum of All Fears]]''<ref name="Forces"/> and ''[[Rulers of Darkness]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yourottawaregion.com/article/1360467--manotick-filmmaker-revives-canadian-ufo-story|title=Manotick filmmaker revives Canadian UFO story|publisher=Your Ottawa Region|date=May 23, 2012}}</ref>
