https://web.archive.org/web/20170712033650/https://www.gaystarnews.com/article/us-surgeon-generals-call-end-intersex-surgery/| archivedate = July 12, 2017| df = }}</ref> citing a State Department statement<ref name="state2016">{{Cite web| last = Department Of State| title = In Recognition of Intersex Awareness Day| author-link = Department of State| date = October 26, 2016| url = https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2016/10/263578.htm| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170904211547/https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2016/10/263578.htm| archivedate = September 4, 2017| df = }}</ref> and developments in [[Intersex rights in Germany|Germany]], [[Intersex rights in Switzerland|Switzerland]], [[Intersex rights in Australia|Australia]], [[Intersex rights in Chile|Chile]], [[Intersex rights in Argentina|Argentina]], and [[Intersex rights in Malta|Malta]], and calling for a rethink of early genital surgeries on children with intersex traits. The statement reflected on the history of such interventions, their rationales and outcomes, stating:
{{quote|When an individual is born with atypical genitalia that pose no physical risk, treatment should focus not on surgical intervention but on psychosocial and educational support for the family and child. Cosmetic genitoplasty should be deferred until children are old enough to voice their own view about whether to undergo the surgery. Those whose oath or conscience says "do no harm" should heed the simple fact that, to date, research does not support the practice of cosmetic infant genitoplasty.}}
===Human Rights Watch/interACT report on U.S. children, 2017=== In July 2017, [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth|interACT]] published a report on medically unnecessary surgeries on intersex children, "I Want to Be Like Nature Made Me", based on interviews with intersex persons, families and physicians.<ref name="hrw2017"/><ref name="hrw2017b" /><ref name="stewart2017" /> The report states that:
{{quote|Intersex people in the United States are subjected to medical practices that can inflict irreversible physical and psychological harm on them starting in infancy, harms that can last throughout their lives. Many of these procedures are done with the stated aim of making it easier for children to grow up "normal" and integrate more easily into society by helping them conform to a particular sex assignment. The results are often catastrophic, the supposed benefits are largely unproven, and there are generally no urgent health considerations at stake}}
The report found that [[intersex medical interventions]] persist as default advice from doctors to parents, despite some change in some regions of the U.S. and claims of improved surgical techniques, resulting in an uneven situation where care differs and a lack of standards of care, but paradigms for care are still based on socio-cultural factors including expectations of "normality" and evidence in support of surgeries remains lacking. "Nearly every parent" in the study reported pressure for their children to undergo surgery, and many reported misinformation. The report calls for a ban on "surgical procedures that seek to alter the gonads, genitals, or internal sex organs of children with atypical sex characteristics too young to participate in the decision, when those procedures both carry a meaningful risk of harm and can be safely deferred."<ref name="hrw2017">{{Cite book| isbn = 978-1-62313-502-7| last1 = Human Rights Watch| author1-link = Human Rights Watch| last2 = interACT| author2-link = Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth| title = "I Want to Be Like Nature Made Me"| date = July 2017| url = https://www.hrw.org/report/2017/07/25/i-want-be-nature-made-me/medically-unnecessary-surgeries-intersex-children-us| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171005133541/https://www.hrw.org/report/2017/07/25/i-want-be-nature-made-me/medically-unnecessary-surgeries-intersex-children-us| archivedate = 2017-10-05| df = }}</ref><ref name="stewart2017">{{Cite web| last = Stewart| first = Philippa| title = Interview: Intersex Babies Don't Need 'Fixing'| work = Human Rights Watch| accessdate = 2017-07-25| date = 2017-07-25| url = https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/07/25/interview-intersex-babies-dont-need-fixing| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170803222257/https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/07/25/interview-intersex-babies-dont-need-fixing| archivedate = 2017-08-03| df = }}</ref><ref name="hrw2017b">{{Cite web| last = Human Rights Watch| title = US: Harmful Surgery on Intersex Children| work = Human Rights Watch| accessdate = 2017-07-25| date = 2017-07-25| url = https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/07/25/us-harmful-surgery-intersex-children| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170803222338/https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/07/25/us-harmful-surgery-intersex-children| archivedate = 2017-08-03| df = }}</ref>
The report was acknowledged as an important contribution to research by the [[American Academy of Pediatrics]].<ref name="aap2017">{{Cite web| last = American Academy of Pediatrics| title = American Academy of Pediatrics Statement in Response to Human Rights Watch Report on Treatment of Children With Differences of Sex Development| date = 2017-07-25| url = https://www.aap.org/en-us/about-the-aap/aap-press-room/Pages/American-Academy-of-Pediatrics-Statement-in-Response-to-Human-Rights-Watch-Report.aspx| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170728075327/https://www.aap.org/en-us/about-the-aap/aap-press-room/Pages/American-Academy-of-Pediatrics-Statement-in-Response-to-Human-Rights-Watch-Report.aspx| archivedate = 2017-07-28| df = }}</ref>
===Responses to developments===
In a 2017 interview for Harper's Magazine, Laurence Baskin, chief of pediatric urology at University of California, San Francisco, told journalist Sarah Topol "that he would recommend early surgery not just for [[5-alpha-reductase deficiency|5-alpha]] but for 95 percent of known D.S.D. conditions ... Baskin classifies such operations as corrective surgeries, no different from fixing a cleft palate or clubfoot. "We basically treat them because they have a congenital anomaly"."<ref name="harpers2017">{{Cite news| issn = 0017-789X| last = Topol| first = Sarah A.| title = Sons and Daughters| work = [[Harper's Magazine]]| accessdate = 2017-07-27| date = August 2017| url = https://harpers.org/archive/2017/08/sons-and-daughters/?single=1| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170729064533/https://harpers.org/archive/2017/08/sons-and-daughters/?single=1| archivedate = 2017-07-29| df = }}</ref>
In response to the 2017 Human Rights Watch report, [[Associated Press]] reported opposition to a ban by CARES Foundation, arguing that parents should be able to agree to surgeries to "reduce the size of the clitoris" without considering "moral and philosophical agendas".<ref name="ap2017">{{Cite web| last = Associated Press| title = Pressure mounts to curtail surgery on intersex children| work = [[ABC News]]| accessdate = 2017-07-27| date = July 25, 2017| url = http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/wireStory/pressure-mounts-curtail-surgery-intersex-children-48828370| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170727115736/http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/wireStory/pressure-mounts-curtail-surgery-intersex-children-48828370| archivedate = July 27, 2017| df = }}</ref> Kyle Knight of [[Human Rights Watch]] responded that there's no evidence of a health risk, and "There are limits to what parents can do to their kids".<ref name="ap2017" /> [[Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth|interACT]] states that they are "unaware of any jurisdiction in the U.S. that enforces its own FGM laws in cases where the girl undergoing clitoral cutting has an intersex trait".<ref name="interactcat">{{Cite conference|last=[[Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth|interACT]]|title=Recommendations from interACT: Advocates for Intersex Youth regarding the List of Issues for the United States for the 59th Session of the Committee Against Torture|date=June 2016|url=http://tbinternet.ohchr.org/Treaties/CAT/Shared%20Documents/USA/INT_CAT_ICS_USA_24552_E.pdf|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170104000043/http://tbinternet.ohchr.org/Treaties/CAT/Shared%20Documents/USA/INT_CAT_ICS_USA_24552_E.pdf|archivedate=2017-01-04|df=}}</ref>
In November 2016, [[GLMA: Health Professionals Advancing LGBT Equality]] passed a new policy position on patients with differences in sex development, recommending "delay of any surgical interventions and gender-related medical interventions for DSD that are not deemed medically necessary".<ref>{{Cite| last = GLMA: Health Professionals Advancing LGBT Equality| author-link = GLMA: Health Professionals Advancing LGBT Equality | title = Medical and Surgical Intervention of Patients with Differences in Sex Development| date = November 2, 2016| url = http://glma.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=document.viewdocument&ID=CEB9FEE4B8DD8B7F4F7575376BD476C3A433379DD853BEA17913AFCCB8270299C0731320B03D2F5E1022F1C15602FBEA}}</ref><ref>{{Cite| last = GLMA: Health Professionals Advancing LGBT Equality| author-link = GLMA: Health Professionals Advancing LGBT Equality | title = GLMA Adopts Resolution on Care for Children with DSD| date = November 2016| url = http://glma.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=Feature.showFeature&CategoryID=1&FeatureID=796}}</ref>
Associated Press reported in July 2017 that the [[American Medical Association]] Board of Trustees is considering a policy statement "urging doctors to defer intersex surgery on infants and young children" "except when life-threatening circumstances require emergency intervention".<ref name="ap2017" />
On August 28, California became the first U.S. State to condemn nonconsensual surgeries on intersex children, in Resolution SCR-110.<ref>{{Cite news| last = Littlefield| first = Amy| title = Intersex People Want to End Nonconsensual Surgeries. A California Resolution Is Their 'Warning Shot.'| work = [[Rewire.News]]| accessdate = 2018-09-05| date = August 13, 2018| url = https://rewire.news/article/2018/08/13/intersex-people-want-to-end-nonconsensual-surgeries-a-california-resolution-is-their-warning-shot/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news| last = Miller| first = Susan| title = California becomes first state to condemn intersex surgeries on children| work = [[USA TODAY]]| accessdate = 2018-09-05| date = August 28, 2018| url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2018/08/28/intersex-surgeries-children-california-first-state-condemn/1126185002/}}</ref>
==Reparations==
===M.C. v. Aaronson=== The case of ''M.C. v. Aaronson'', advanced by [[Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth|interACT]] with the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] was brought before the courts in 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://interactadvocates.org/aics-landmark-lawsuit-makes-history/ | work = [[Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth|AIC]] | title = AIC's Landmark Lawsuit Makes History! | date = May 16, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170206105423/http://interactadvocates.org/aics-landmark-lawsuit-makes-history/ | archivedate = February 6, 2017 | df = }}</ref><ref name="splc2013">{{cite web |url=http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/news/groundbreaking-splc-lawsuit-accuses-south-carolina-doctors-and-hospitals-of-unnece |title=Groundbreaking SLPC Lawsuit Accuses South Carolina Doctors and Hospitals of Unnecessary Surgery on Infant |last1=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]] |date=May 14, 2013 |website= |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-20 |quote= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713101437/http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/news/groundbreaking-splc-lawsuit-accuses-south-carolina-doctors-and-hospitals-of-unnece |archivedate=July 13, 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://nursingclio.org/2013/05/17/do-no-harm-intersex-surgeries-and-the-limits-of-certainty/ |title=Do No Harm: Intersex Surgeries and the Limits of Certainty |last1=Reis |first1=Elizabeth |date=May 17, 2013 |website=Nursing Clio |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-20 |quote= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225040721/http://nursingclio.org/2013/05/17/do-no-harm-intersex-surgeries-and-the-limits-of-certainty/ |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/05/when-to-do-surgery-on-a-child-with-both-genitalia/275884/ |title=When to Do Surgery on a Child With 'Both' Genitalia |last1=Dreger |first1=Alice |author1-link=Alice Dreger |date=May 16, 2013 |website=[[The Atlantic]] |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-20 |quote= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150720195339/http://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/05/when-to-do-surgery-on-a-child-with-both-genitalia/275884/ |archivedate=July 20, 2015 |df= }}</ref> The child in the case was born in December 2004 with [[True hermaphroditism|ovotestes]], initially determined as male, but subsequently assigned female and placed in the care of South Carolina Department of Social Services in February 2005.<ref name="white2013">{{Cite journal| volume = 37| pages = 777| last = White| first = Ryan L.| title = Preferred Private Parts: Importing Intersex Autonomy for M.C. v. Aaronson| url = http://ir.lawnet.fordham.edu/ilj/vol37/iss3/2| journal = Fordham International Law Journal| date = 2013| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170323234718/http://ir.lawnet.fordham.edu/ilj/vol37/iss3/2/| archivedate = 2017-03-23| df = }}</ref> Physicians responsible for M.C. initially concluded that surgery was not urgent or necessary and M.C. had potential to identify as male or female, but, in April 2006, M.C. was subjected to feminizing medical interventions.<ref name="white2013" /> He was adopted in December 2006. Aged 8 at the time the case was taken, he now identifies as male. The Southern Poverty Law Center states: "In M.C.'s condition, there is no way to tell whether the child will ultimately identify as a boy or a girl. Instead, the doctors decided to assign M.C. female and change his body to fit their stereotype of how a girl should look."<ref name="splc2013" /><ref>{{cite news | work = [[Washington Times]] | title = Adoptive parents sue over son's sex-assignment surgery | url = http://communities.washingtontimes.com/neighborhood/world-our-backyard/2013/may/18/adoptive-parents-sue-over-sons-sex-assignment-surg/ | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130522132342/http://communities.washingtontimes.com/neighborhood/world-our-backyard/2013/may/18/adoptive-parents-sue-over-sons-sex-assignment-surg/ | archivedate = 2013-05-22 | df = }}</ref> The defendant in the case, Dr Ian Aaronson, had written in 2001 that "feminizing genitoplasty on an infant who might eventually identify herself as a boy would be catastrophic".<ref name="aaronson2001">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1067/mps.2001.116127| issn = 0045-9380| volume = 31| issue = 6| pages = 168–194| last = Aaronson| first = Ian A| title = The investigation and management of the infant with ambiguous genitalia: A surgeon's perspective| journal = Current Problems in Pediatrics| date = July 2001| url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1538544201000487| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180104224642/http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1538544201000487| archivedate = 2018-01-04| df = }}</ref><ref name="white2013" />
The defendants sought to dismiss the case and seek a defense of qualified immunity, but these were denied by the District Court for the District of South Carolina. In January 2015, the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit reversed this decision and dismissed the complaint, stating that, "it did not "mean to diminish the severe harm that M.C. claims to have suffered" but that a reasonable official in 2006 did not have fair warning from then-existing precedent that performing sex assignment surgery on sixteen-month-old M.C. violated a clearly established constitutional right."<ref name="largent2015">{{cite web | url = http://blogs.harvard.edu/billofhealth/2015/03/05/m-c-v-aaronson-update/ | title = M.C. v. Aaronson | first = Emily | last = Largent | work = Petrie-Flom Center, Harvard Law | date = March 5, 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170218235654/http://blogs.harvard.edu/billofhealth/2015/03/05/m-c-v-aaronson-update/ | archivedate = February 18, 2017 | df = }}</ref> The Court did not rule on whether or not the surgery violated M.C.'s constitutional rights.<ref>{{Cite web| last = interACT| authorlink = Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth| title = Update on M.C.'s Case – The Road to Justice can be Long, but there is more than one path for M.C.| accessdate = 2017-02-18| date = January 27, 2015| url = http://interactadvocates.org/update-on-the-m-c-case-the-road-to-justice-can-be-long/| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170219013202/http://interactadvocates.org/update-on-the-m-c-case-the-road-to-justice-can-be-long/| archivedate = February 19, 2017| df = }}</ref> State suits were subsequently filed.<ref name="largent2015" />
In July 2017, it was reported that the case had been settled out of court by the Medical University of South Carolina for $440,000. The University denied negligence, but agreed to a "compromise" settlement to avoid "costs of litigation."<ref name="ghorayshi2017">{{Cite web| last = Ghorayshi| first = Azeen| title = A Landmark Lawsuit About An Intersex Baby's Genital Surgery Just Settled For $440,000| work = BuzzFeed| accessdate = 2017-07-27| date = July 27, 2017| url = https://www.buzzfeed.com/azeenghorayshi/intersex-surgery-lawsuit-settles| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170727175528/https://www.buzzfeed.com/azeenghorayshi/intersex-surgery-lawsuit-settles| archivedate = July 27, 2017| df = }}</ref>
==Protection from discrimination== [[File:Inclusion of sex characteristics in anti-discrimination law.svg|thumb|right|260px| {{legend|#002255|Explicit protection from [[Discrimination against intersex people|discrimination]] on grounds of [[sex characteristics]]}} {{legend|#0066FF|Explicit protection on grounds of intersex status}} {{legend|#9FCFFF|Explicit protection on grounds of intersex within attribute of sex}}]] {{main|Discrimination against intersex people}} In May 2016, the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]] issued a statement explaining Section 1557 of the [[Affordable Care Act]] stating that the Act prohibits "discrimination on the basis of intersex traits or atypical sex characteristics" in publicly-funded healthcare, as part of a prohibition of discrimination "on the basis of sex".<ref name="interacthealth">{{cite web| last = [[Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth|interACT]]| title = Federal Government Bans Discrimination Against Intersex People in Health Care| work = interactadvocates| accessdate = 2016-05-27| url = http://interactadvocates.org/federal-government-bans-discrimination-against-intersex-people-in-health-care/| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160528104341/http://interactadvocates.org/federal-government-bans-discrimination-against-intersex-people-in-health-care/| archivedate = 2016-05-28| df = }}</ref><ref name="ocr">{{cite web| last = Office for Civil Rights (OCR)| title = Section 1557 of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act| work = HHS.gov| format = Text| accessdate = 2016-05-27| date = 2016| url = https://www.hhs.gov/civil-rights/for-individuals/section-1557/index.html| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160529015028/http://www.hhs.gov/civil-rights/for-individuals/section-1557/index.html| archivedate = 2016-05-29| df = }}</ref>
Intersex persons are also protected by the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]].<ref name="menon2011">{{Cite journal| volume = 43| issue = 4| pages = 1221–1251| last = Menon| first = Yamuna| title = The Intersex Community and the Americans with Disabilities Act| journal = Connecticut Law Review| date = May 2011| url = http://connecticutlawreview.org/articles/the-intersex-community-and-the-americans-with-disabilities-act/| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170202084505/http://connecticutlawreview.org/articles/the-intersex-community-and-the-americans-with-disabilities-act/| archivedate = 2017-02-02| df = }}</ref>
In 2017, interACT submitted an [[amicus curiae]] in the matter of Gavin Grimm (G.G. v. Gloucester County School Board) regarding protections in education for issues of [[gender identity under Title IX]]. The submission stated that the Gloucester County School Board held a "simplistic view of "physiological" sex [that] is demonstrably inaccurate as a matter of human biology. Moreover, it demeans many thousands of intersex youth by erasing their bodies and lives and placing them outside the recognition of the law".<ref name="interact2017gg">{{Cite| last = interACT| title = Brief of interACT: Advocates for Intersex Youth, et al., as Amici Curiae in support of respondent. G.G., by his next friend and mother, Deirdre Grimm| date = March 2017}}</ref>
==Identification documents== {{main|Legal recognition of intersex people}}
===Third sex classifications===
On [[Intersex Awareness Day]] (October 26) 2015, [[Lambda Legal]] filed a federal discrimination lawsuit against the [[United States Department of State]] for denying [[non-binary]] intersex navy veteran, [[Dana Zzyym]], Associate Director of [[Intersex Campaign for Equality]], a passport.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.lambdalegal.org/blog/20151026_zzyym-intersex-denied-passport | title = Lambda Legal Sues U.S. State Department on Behalf of Intersex Citizen Denied Passport | work = [[Lambda Legal]] | date = October 26, 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170221091615/http://www.lambdalegal.org/blog/20151026_zzyym-intersex-denied-passport | archivedate = February 21, 2017 | df = }}</ref> On November 22, 2016, the District Court for the District of Colorado ruled in favor of Zzyym, stating that the State Department violated federal law.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.washingtonblade.com/2016/11/23/judge-rules-favor-intersex-passport-applicant/ | title = Judge rules in favor of intersex passport applicant | last = Lavers | first = Michael | work = [[Washington Blade]] | date = November 23, 2016 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170202070901/http://www.washingtonblade.com/2016/11/23/judge-rules-favor-intersex-passport-applicant/ | archivedate = February 2, 2017 | df = }}</ref> The ruling stated that the court found "no evidence that the Department followed a rational decision-making process in deciding to implement its binary-only gender passport policy," and ordered the U.S. Passport Agency to reconsider its earlier decision.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.lambdalegal.org/in-court/legal-docs/zzyym_co_20161122_order | title = Order: Zzymm v Kerry and Portell | work = [[Lambda Legal]] | accessdate = 2017-01-30 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170202063617/http://www.lambdalegal.org/in-court/legal-docs/zzyym_co_20161122_order | archivedate = 2017-02-02 | df = }}</ref>
On September 26, 2016, California resident Sara Kelly Keenan became described as the second person in the United States to legally change her gender to non-binary. Keenan, who uses she/her pronouns, identifies as intersex "both as my medical reality and as my gender identification ... It never occurred to me that this was an option, because I thought the gender change laws were strictly for transgender people. I decided to try and use the same framework to have a third gender."<ref name="nbcnews.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/californian-becomes-second-us-citizen-granted-non-binary-gender-status-n654611|title=Californian Becomes Second US Citizen Granted 'Non-Binary' Gender Status|date=September 26, 2016|work=[[NBC News]]|last1=O'Hara|first1=Mary Emily|accessdate=September 26, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160926204210/http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/californian-becomes-second-us-citizen-granted-non-binary-gender-status-n654611|archivedate=September 26, 2016|df=}}</ref> In December 2016, Keenan received a birth certificate with an 'Intersex' sex marker from New York City, the first birth certificate issued using this term in the United States. Keenan had applied for a "non-binary" birth certificate but the City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene required a biological term.<ref>{{cite web | last = Scutti | first = Susan | title = NYC issues nation's first "intersex" birth certificate | work = CNN | date = December 30, 2016 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2016/12/30/health/intersex-birth-certificate/index.html | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170205153834/http://www.cnn.com/2016/12/30/health/intersex-birth-certificate/index.html | archivedate = February 5, 2017 | df = }}</ref>
Press coverage in December 2016 also disclosed that Ohio issued a birth certificate with a sex marker of 'hermaphrodite' in 2012. Ohio issues birth certificates based on "an historical record of the facts as they existed at the time of birth" and the individual was able to demonstrate a diagnosis of [[true hermaphrodite]].<ref name="ohara2016">{{cite web| last = O'Hara| first = Mary Emily| title = Nation's First Known Intersex Birth Certificate Issued in NYC| accessdate = 2016-12-30| date = December 29, 2016| url = http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/nation-s-first-known-intersex-birth-certificate-issued-nyc-n701186| work = [[NBC News]]| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161230121426/http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/nation-s-first-known-intersex-birth-certificate-issued-nyc-n701186| archivedate = December 30, 2016| df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oxygen.com/very-real/first-ever-intersex-birth-certificate-issued-in-america |title=First Ever Intersex Birth Certificate Issued In America | Very Real |publisher=Oxygen.com |date=2016-12-30 |accessdate=2017-01-04 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105084411/http://www.oxygen.com/very-real/first-ever-intersex-birth-certificate-issued-in-america |archivedate=2017-01-05 |df= }}</ref> Birth certificates are also known to have no sex specified.
==Right to life== {{main|Genetic diagnosis of intersex}} Robert Sparrow has stated that the genetic elimination of intersex traits might be permissible, despite "uncomfortable" implications for "other nonpathological human variations" that do not affect physical health.<ref name="sparrow2013">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1080/15265161.2013.828115| issn = 1526-5161 | volume = 13| issue = 10| pages = 29–38| last = Sparrow| first = Robert| title = Gender Eugenics? The Ethics of PGD for Intersex Conditions| journal = The American Journal of Bioethics| date = October 2013| url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/15265161.2013.828115}}</ref> In response, [[Georgiann Davis]] argues that such discrimination fails to recognize that many people with intersex traits led full and happy lives, and that the "intersex community is only "invisible" to those who choose to ignore it", while "the medical profession, not the intersex trait itself, is a major source of the social and psychological harm that perpetuates intersex stigmatization and the "hostile social environment" that individuals with intersex traits encounter".<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1080/15265161.2013.828119| issn = 1526-5161| volume = 13| issue = 10| pages = 51–53| last = Davis| first = Georgiann| author-link=Georgiann Davis|title = The Social Costs of Preempting Intersex Traits| journal = The American Journal of Bioethics| date = October 2013| url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/15265161.2013.828119| pmid=24024811}}</ref> Jason Behrmann and Vardit Ravitsky state that: "Parental choice against intersex may ... conceal biases against same-sex attractedness and gender nonconformity."<ref name="Behrmann2013">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1080/15265161.2013.828131| pmid = 24024805 | issn = 1526-5161 | volume = 13| issue = 10| pages = 39–41| last1 = Behrmann| first1 = Jason| last2 = Ravitsky| first2 = Vardit| title = Queer Liberation, Not Elimination: Why Selecting Against Intersex is Not "Straight" Forward| journal = The American Journal of Bioethics| date = October 2013| url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/15265161.2013.828131}}</ref>
==Rights advocacy==
Notable intersex rights organizations include [[Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth|interACT]] and [[Intersex Campaign for Equality]]. Former intersex rights organizations include the [[Intersex Society of North America]].
Notable advocates include [[Eden Atwood]], [[Max Beck]], [[Cheryl Chase (activist)|Cheryl Chase]], [[Cary Gabriel Costello]], [[Georgiann Davis]], [[Tiger Devore]], [[Alice Dreger]], [[Pidgeon Pagonis]], [[Anne Tamar-Mattis]], [[Hida Viloria]], [[Sean Saifa Wall]] and [[Kimberly Zieselman]].
Personal testimonies are detailed in the San Francisco Human Rights Commission report, and also in a 2015 issue of [[Narrative Inquiry in Bioethics]],<ref>{{cite journal|first=Georgiann|last=Davis|authorlink=Georgiann Davis|title=Voices: Personal Stories from the Pages of NIB|journal=[[Narrative Inquiry in Bioethics]]|date=2015|volume=5|issue=2|publisher=[[Johns Hopkins University Press]]|url=http://www.nibjournal.org/news/documents/Voices_2016_OA_FINAL-withOLOS_version_001.pdf|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109185051/http://www.nibjournal.org/news/documents/Voices_2016_OA_FINAL-withOLOS_version_001.pdf|archivedate=2017-01-09|df=}}</ref> and a [[Lambda Literary Award]] winning<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=21st_Lambda_Literary_Awards&oldid=844604909|title=21st Lambda Literary Awards|date=5 June 2018|publisher=|via=Wikipedia}}</ref> book, ''Intersex (For Lack of a Better Word),'' by Thea Hillman.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = [[Manic D Press]], Inc.| last = Hillman| first = Thea| title = Intersex (For Lack of a Better Word)| date = 2008}}</ref> Movies include the short, award-winning film ''[[XXXY (film)|XXXY]]'' (2000). In 2017, [[Hatchette Book Group]] published a memoir, ''Born Both'', by [[Hida Viloria]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://hidaviloria.com/about/articles-essays-other-published-work-by-hida-viloria/ | title = Articles, essays, other published work by Hida Viloria | accessdate = 2017-02-05 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160122034955/http://hidaviloria.com/about/articles-essays-other-published-work-by-hida-viloria/ | archivedate = 2016-01-22 | df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Viloria | first = Hida | author-link = Hida Viloria | url = https://www.hachettebookgroup.com/titles/hida-viloria/born-both/9781478940715/ | title = Born Both | work = [[Hatchette Book Group]] | accessdate = 2017-02-05 | isbn = 9781478940715 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170206104341/https://www.hachettebookgroup.com/titles/hida-viloria/born-both/9781478940715/ | archivedate = 2017-02-06 | df = }}</ref>

An '''Island Commander''' is an official who is put in charge of an island, or an insular entity called after an island or an archipelago called Islands.
The United States have used the title for several of their overseas insular possessions, considered too small to have a higher official such as a (Lieutenant) [[Governor]] :
; Presently : * [[Wake Island]] since July 4, 1898 till present
; Formerly : * Two of the three islands that previously had been under the two consecutive heads of the [[American Equatorial Islands Colonization Project]], 1935 - February 7, 1942 ([[Jarvis Island]] only had an international [[Station Chief]] afterwards): ** [[Baker Island]]: September 1943 - May 1944 (incumbents unknown); September 1943 - May 1944 while occupied by U.S. military forces (Baker Naval Air Station). Since June 27, 1974 it is administered by the [[U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service]] as Baker Island National Wildlife Refuge. ** [[Johnston Atoll]]: 1934–2003; on January 1, 2004, the island was turned over to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service as Johnston Atoll Wildlife Refuge * [[Midway Islands]] June 1940 – October 31, 1996; since administered by the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service as Midway Island National Wildlife Refuge * [[Palmyra Atoll]] November 1939 - 1947 while occupied by U.S. military forces. Since August 15, 1941 it harbored the Palmyra U.S. Naval Air Station, now [[Palmyra (Cooper) Airport]].
== Sources and references == * [http://www.worldstatesmen.org/COLONIES.html#United%20States World Statesmen - U.S. possessions]

page.title: List of things named for Henry Clay

revision.text:
[[File:Clay portrait.jpg|thumb|Henry Clay]] The following is a list of things named for [[Henry Clay]], as well as monuments and memorials in his honor.
==Roads== * Henry Clay Boulevard and Clay Avenue in [[Lexington, Kentucky]] * Henry Clay Boulevard in [[Ashland, Missouri]] * Clay Streets in numerous cities, including [[New Haven, Connecticut]], [[Richmond, Virginia]], [[Vicksburg, Mississippi]] and [[Whitefish Bay, Wisconsin]]. * Ashland Ave. in [[Chicago]], Illinois; [[Ashland, Virginia]], Ashland County in Ohio and Wisconsin were named for his estate, as were the cities of Ashland in Kentucky, Alabama, and Pennsylvania. * Henry Clay Court in [[The Landings]] on [[Skidaway Island]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]
==Towns== * [[Ashland, Missouri]], was named after Clay's Lexington, Kentucky estate. * [[Clay, New York|Clay, in Onondaga County, New York]], including the road Henry Clay Boulevard. Also, Clayville in Oneida County, New York. * [[Clay, Kentucky]] in western Kentucky is named in honor of Clay. * Henry Clay Village, or [[Breck's Mill Area]], on the left bank of [[Brandywine Creek (Christina River)|Brandywine Creek]] in [[Wilmington, Delaware]], factory and mill worker's residences. * The town of [[Claysburg, Pennsylvania|Claysburg]] in central Pennsylvania is named in honor of Clay. * [[Clayville, Illinois]] was an active settlement during the statesman's life. * [[Claysville, Alabama]] is named in honor of Clay.
==Counties== * Sixteen Clay counties in the United States, in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Nebraska, North Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, and West Virginia. ([[Clay County, Iowa]] is named for his son [[Henry Clay Jr.]])
==Monuments== [[File:Henry Clay's grave in Lexington - DSC09049.JPG|thumb|Tomb in Lexington, KY]] [[File:MugnierClayStatueCanalB.jpg|thumb|Henry Clay Monument in New Orleans ca.1890]] * Memorial column and statue at his tomb in [[Lexington, Kentucky]] * [[Henry Clay (Niehaus)|Statue of Clay]] in the [[National Statuary Hall Collection]], [[United States Capitol|Capitol]], [[Washington D.C.]] * Henry Clay statue and portrait in [[Virginia State Capitol]] in [[Richmond, Virginia]] * Henry Clay monument in [[Pottsville, Pennsylvania]]<ref>[http://www.schuylkillhistory.org/henryclay.html Historical Society of Schuylkill County :: The Henry Clay Monument in Pottsville<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204211453/http://www.schuylkillhistory.org/henryclay.html |date=2012-02-04 }}. * Henry Clay statue in [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Henry_Clay_Statue,_New_Orleans Lafayette Square, New Orleans, LA]</ref>
==Other== * [[Mount Clay]] in the [[Presidential Range]] of [[New Hampshire]] was named for Clay, since renamed [[Mount Reagan]] by the state legislature but not by the federal Board on Geographic Names * In [[New Orleans]]: uptown – Henry Clay Avenue, and downtown – a 20-foot-tall monument erected in 1860 at [[Canal Street, New Orleans|Canal Street]] and [[St. Charles Avenue]]/[[Royal Street, New Orleans|Royal Street]], and moved to the center of [[Lafayette Square, New Orleans|Lafayette Square]] in 1901. * Many schools throughout the U.S., including [[Clay High School (Indiana)|Clay High School]] in [[South Bend, Indiana]], [[Henry Clay High School]] in [[Lexington, Kentucky]],<ref>[http://www.henryclay.fcps.net/ Henry Clay High School Home Page].</ref> Henry Clay Middle School in [[Los Angeles]], California, Henry Clay Elementary School in the [[Hegewisch]] neighborhood in [[Chicago]], Henry Clay School in [[Whitefish Bay, Wisconsin]] and Henry Clay Elementary School in his birthplace, [[Hanover County, Virginia]]. * The Instituto Educacional Henry Clay in [[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]], a bilingual private school * The Clay Dormitory at [[Transylvania University]] in [[Lexington, Kentucky]] * The [[Lafayette class submarine]] [[USS Henry Clay (SSBN-625)|USS ''Henry Clay'' (SSBN-625)]], the only ship of the [[United States Navy]] named in his honor, although the {{USS|Ashland|LSD-1}} and {{USS|Ashland|LSD-48}} are named for his estate * Clay is one of the many senators honored with a [[cenotaph]] in the [[Congressional Cemetery]]. * Between 1870 and 1908, Clay was invariably included in the pantheon of Great Americans presented on U. S. definitive postage stamps: he appeared on the 12¢ denomination in the issues of 1870, 1873 and 1879 and on the 15¢ denomination in the issues of 1890, 1894, 1898 and 1902. He has since been honored by the [[United States Postal Service]] with a 3¢ [[Great Americans series]] [[postage stamp]]. * Cooper's Rock State Forest in West Virginia features a preserved nineteenth century iron furnace named in commemoration of Henry Clay. * The Henry Clay, an historic upscale residential building in downtown Louisville, KY, formerly the city's YWCA building.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{primary sources|date=May 2012}} '''Living Liberally''' is the general name for a multifaceted, grassroots progressive community-building movement started in New York City in 2003. The inception of [[Drinking Liberally]] and its parent organization, until 2008 known as '''Cosmopolity''', united a growing progressive social network under one name. According to the website, Living Liberally's goal is "providing easy entrance into progressive involvement, using social interaction to promote political action and facilitating collaboration among progressive organizations."<ref>[http://cosmopolity.org/calendar/bin/about ''Cosmopolity.org''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222002910/http://cosmopolity.org/calendar/bin/about |date=2007-12-22 }} "About Us"</ref> Current Living Liberally projects include Drinking Liberally, [[Laughing Liberally]], [[Screening Liberally]], [[Reading Liberally]], and [[Eating Liberally]]. The majority of Living Liberally projects are organized by volunteers rather than the national organizers. Living Liberally was founded by [[David Alpert]], [[Katrina Baker]], [[Matthew O'Neill (filmmaker)|Matthew O'Neill]], and [[Justin Krebs]].<ref>[http://livingliberally.org/living/about ''Living Liberally''] "About"</ref>
In April, 2007, the 200th chapter of Drinking Liberally was created in [[Pagosa Springs, Colorado]].<ref name="Bowers_Apr-07">[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/chris-bowers/drinking-liberally-reache_b_46106.html "Drinking Liberally Reaches 200"] ''The Huffington Post'' April 17, 2007</ref>

| footnotes = | intl = <!-- Set positively ("true"/"yes"/etc) if company is international, otherwise omit --> }} '''Move, Inc.''' is a real estate listing company based in [[Santa Clara, California]]. The company operates the Move Network of real estate websites, the largest of which is [[Realtor.com]]. Move has a longstanding partnership with the [[National Association of Realtors]], the real estate industry's largest [[trade association]], for operating Realtor.com.<ref name="Logan">{{cite news|last1=Logan|first1=Tim|title=News Corp. to buy parent of realtor.com for $950 million|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-1001-newscorp-realtor-20141001-story.html|accessdate=July 7, 2017|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tronc]]|date=September 30, 2014|issn=0458-3035|oclc=3638237}}</ref><ref name="Collins">{{cite news|last1=Collins|first1=Jeff|title=Zillow to pay Realtor.com $130 million over trade secrets|url=http://www.ocregister.com/2016/06/07/zillow-to-pay-realtorcom-130-million-over-trade-secrets/|accessdate=July 7, 2017|work=[[Orange County Register]]|publisher=[[Digital First Media]]|date=June 7, 2016|location=Anaheim, California|issn=0886-4934|oclc=12199155}}</ref>
==Operations== Move was established in Delaware under the name InfoTouch Corporation in 1993.<ref name="10K">{{cite web|title=Form 10-K: Move, Inc.|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1085770/000104746914000986/a2218258z10-k.htm|publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]|accessdate=July 31, 2017|date=December 31, 2013|page=6}}</ref> The company is based in [[Santa Clara, California]], and operates Move.com and [[Realtor.com]].<ref name="NYT">{{cite news|title=News Corp. to Buy Move, a Real Estate Listings Site|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/09/30/news-corporation-to-buy-move-a-real-estate-listings-site/|accessdate=July 26, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|first1= Michael J.|last1=de la Merced|first2=Emily|last2=Steel|date=September 30, 2014|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|issn=0362-4331|oclc=1645522}}</ref> Move's portfolio of software businesses includes FiveStreet, ListHub, Market Snapshot, Reesio, and Top Producer.<ref name=10K/> The company also operates Doorsteps.com (following its acquisition in 2013), MortgageMatch.com, Moving.com, Relocation.com, and SeniorHousingnet.com,<ref name=10K/> among other online properties.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sullivan|first1=Heather|title=CoStar is hiring about 230 workers in Richmond this year|url=http://www.nbc12.com/story/35089091/costar-is-hiring-about-230-workers-in-richmond-this-year|accessdate=July 31, 2017|publisher=[[WWBT]]|date=April 6, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Berkowitz">{{cite journal|last1=Donato-Weinstein|first1=Nathan|title=Move Inc. CEO Steven Berkowitz on what's next after News Corp buy|journal=Silicon Valley Business Journal|date=September 30, 2014|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2014/09/30/move-inc-ceo-steven-berkowitz-on-whats-next-after.html|accessdate=July 31, 2017}}</ref>
Ryan O'Hara serves as the [[chief executive officer]] (CEO) of Move and Realtor.com.<ref name="Trejos">{{cite news|last1=Trejos|first1=Nancy|title=Airbnb, Realtor.com team up to let you try before you buy|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/destinations/2015/06/24/airbnb-test-homes-realtorcom/29206325/|accessdate=July 7, 2017|work=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|date=June 24, 2015|issn=0734-7456}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Hagey|first1=Paul|title=Move CEO Ryan O'Hara: 'We're a safer option'|url=https://www.inman.com/2015/08/06/move-ceo-ryan-ohara-were-a-safer-option/|website=Inman.com|accessdate=July 31, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Scheinin">{{cite news|last1=Scheinin|first1=Richard|title=Q&A: Realtor.com CEO Ryan O’Hara talks online real estate|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2016/05/18/qa-realtor-com-ceo-ryan-ohara-talks-online-real-estate/|accessdate=July 7, 2017|work=[[The Mercury News]]|publisher=Digital First Media|date=May 18, 2016|location=San Jose, California|issn=0747-2099|oclc=145122249}}</ref> Since August 2015, Nate Johnson has been Move's [[chief marketing officer]], and Bryan Charap has served as [[chief financial officer]].<ref name="Moves">{{cite news|title=CFO Moves: Endurance International Group, TPG Specialty Lending, Move Inc., BrainStorm Cell Therapeutics|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/cfo/2015/08/03/cfo-moves-endurance-international-group-tpg-specialty-lending-move-inc-brainstorm-cell-therapeutics/|accessdate=July 26, 2017|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=August 3, 2015|publisher=[[News Corporation]] ([[Dow Jones & Company]])|issn=0099-9660|oclc=781541372}}</ref><ref name="Soper">{{cite news|last1=Soper|first1=Taylor|title=Tech Moves: Zillow promotes Kathleen Phillips to CFO, Amy Bohutinsky to COO; Shauna Causey joins Galvanize; and more|url=https://www.geekwire.com/2015/tech-moves-zillow-promotes-kathleen-phillips-to-cfo-amy-bohutinsky-to-coo-shauna-causey-joins-galvanize-and-more/|accessdate=July 26, 2017|work=[[GeekWire]]|date=August 3, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Bolsters">{{cite web|title=Move bolsters leadership team with 3 new hires and 1 promotion|url=https://www.inman.com/2015/08/04/move-bolsters-leadership-team-with-3-new-hires-and-1-promotion/|website=Inman.com|accessdate=July 26, 2017|date=August 4, 2015}}</ref> Suhail Ansari was named [[chief technology officer]] in November 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Move appoints Suhail Ansari as its new CTO|url=https://www.inman.com/2015/11/23/move-appoints-suhail-ansari-as-its-new-cto/|website=Inman.com|accessdate=July 26, 2017}}</ref> Chung Meng Cheong became [[chief product officer]] in April 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wiggin|first1=Teke|title=Realtor.com hires new chief product officer, Chung Meng Cheong|url=https://www.inman.com/2017/04/06/realtor-com-hires-new-chief-product-officer-chung-meng-cheong/|website=Inman.com|accessdate=July 26, 2017}}</ref>
==History== ===Homestore=== Stuart Wolff founded the online real estate company Homestore Inc. in 1996.<ref name=Egelko>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/01/15/BUDSUF57V.DTL&feed=rss.business|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|title=Homestore CEO's fraud conviction overturned|first=Bob|last=Egelko|date=January 15, 2008|accessdate=July 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Wedner1">{{cite news|last1=Wedner|first1=Diane|title=Homestore's New Management Trying to Put House in Order|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/feb/27/business/fi-homestore27|accessdate=July 28, 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|date=February 27, 2002|page=1}}</ref> He established a partnership with the [[National Association of Realtors]], and his company, RealSelect Inc., operated [[Realtor.com]]. Under the agreement, the National Association of Realtors had a small stake in RealSelect.<ref name=Wedner1/>
The company went public as Homestore.com, Inc. in 1999,<ref name=10K/> and was traded on the [[NASDAQ]] stock exchange.<ref name=Completes>{{Cite web|url=https://www.inman.com/2014/11/14/news-corp-completes-acquisition-of-move/|title=News Corp. closes realtor.com deal|date=November 14, 2014|website=Inman.com|first=Paul|last=Hagey|accessdate=July 26, 2017}}</ref> In October 2000, Homestore agreed to purchase Move.com from Cendant Corp. for $761 million in stock, leaving Cendant with a 15 percent stake.<ref name="Wedner3">{{cite news|last1=Wedner|first1=Diane|title=Homestore's New Management Trying to Put House in Order|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/feb/27/business/fi-homestore27/3|accessdate=July 26, 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|date=February 27, 2002|page=3}}</ref><ref name="Monroe">{{cite news|last1=Monroe|first1=Robert|title=Homestore.com Buys Rival Move.com Acquired in Deal Worth $761 Million.|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-83397306.html|accessdate=July 31, 2017|work=Daily News|date=October 28, 2000|via=HighBeam Research|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Homestore acquires move.com.|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-67720445.html|accessdate=July 31, 2017|work=Real Estate Weekly|date=November 8, 2000|via=HighBeam Research|subscription=yes}}</ref> In 2001, Homestore operated the websites HomeBuilder.com, HomeFair.com, Realtor.com, and SpringStreet.com, acquired HomeBid, and owned the software Top Producer as well as Wyldfyre technologies.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kersnar|first1=Scott|title=Homestore Continues Buying Spree.|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-71193624.html|accessdate=August 2, 2017|work=National Mortgage News|date=March 5, 2001|via=HighBeam Research|subscription=yes}}</ref> In August, the company purchased iPlace Inc., for $150 million.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Loyd|first1=Linda|title=Homestore.com to absorb IPlace.|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-77111729.html|accessdate=August 2, 2017|work=Knight Ridder/Tribune News Service|date=August 10, 2001|via=HighBeam Research|subscription=yes}}</ref>
During the rise of the [[dot-com bubble]], Wolff was convicted of [[insider trading]] and falsifying revenue results, and several additional executives received prison sentences for inflating earnings.<ref name="Carter">{{cite web|last1=Carter|first1=Matt|title=Wolff sentenced to 4.5 years in prison|url=https://www.inman.com/2010/04/19/wolff-sentenced-45-years-in-prison/|website=Inman.com|accessdate=July 28, 2017|date=April 19, 2010}}</ref> Homestore's 2000 and 2001 financial reports required refiling, and the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] investigated the company in 2002.<ref name=Egelko/><ref name=Wedner1/> Wolff's conviction was overturned on appeal in 2008,<ref name=Egelko/> but he eventually plea bargained for a sentence of 3–5 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inman.com/news/2010/01/11/stuart-wolff-plead-guilty|title=Stuart Wolff pleads guilty|first=Matt|last=Carter|date=January 11, 2010|accessdate=July 28, 2017|website=Inman.com}}</ref> Wolff resigned as CEO in January 2002,<ref name=Egelko/> and was replaced by a new management team.<ref name=Wedner1/>
Homestore.com, Inc. changed its name to Homestore, Inc. in 2002, then rebranded as Move, Inc. in 2006.<ref name=10K/><ref name=Carter/><ref>{{cite news|title=Homestore renamed move.|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-145468633.html|accessdate=August 2, 2017|work=Units|date=April 1, 2006|via=HighBeam Research|subscription=yes}}</ref> The company's stock symbol was changed from "HOMS" to "MOVE", and the Move.com website was launched in May 2006.<ref name="Bruce">{{cite news|last1=Bruce|first1=Allison|title=Move.com adds resources for real estate customers.|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-146512018.html|accessdate=July 31, 2017|work=Ventura County Star|date=May 29, 2006|via=HighBeam Research|subscription=yes}}</ref>
===Move, Inc.=== Move acquired the company Threewide, which operated the real estate listing service ListHub, for $13 million in September 2010. Move retained ListHub as its own separate brand.<ref name="Wauters">{{cite news|last1=Wauters|first1=Robin|title=Move Acquires Online Real Estate Listing Syndicator ListHub For $13 Million|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/09/21/move-threewide-listhub/|accessdate=July 25, 2017|work=[[TechCrunch]]|date=September 21, 2010}}</ref> Move launched an online mortgage offering called MortgageMatch.com in December 2010, targeting first time home buyers and those looking to refinance,<ref>{{cite news|title=Mortgage Match Targets First-time Homebuyers|url=http://www.upi.com/Real-Estate/2010/12/01/Mortgage-Match-Targets-First-time-Homebuyers/9811291222331/|accessdate=July 28, 2017|publisher=[[United Press International]]|date=December 1, 2010}}</ref> then acquired the social search platform SocialBios in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Move Acquires SocialBios, Social Search Platform.|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-278254877.html|accessdate=August 2, 2017|work=Online Product News|date=August 1, 2011|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam Research}}</ref> In 2013, Move reported $227 million in revenue and $600,000 in profit.<ref name=NYT/> Move ended its three-year partnership with AOL real estate in December 2013, and its decade-long partnership with MSN Real Estate in July 2014.<ref name="TakesOver">{{cite web|last1=Hagey|first1=Paul|title=Zillow takes over real estate search at MSN Real Estate after Move Inc.'s exit|url=https://www.inman.com/2014/07/01/zillow-takes-over-real-estate-search-at-msn-real-estate-for-move-inc/|website=Inman.com|accessdate=July 28, 2017}}</ref>
In September 2014, [[News Corporation]] agreed to purchase Move for $950 million, marking the former company's largest acquisition to date.<ref name=Logan/> Move operated the third most-trafficked website network for U.S. listings at the time.<ref name="Parent">{{cite news|last1=Logan|first1=Tim|title=Murdoch's News Corp. to buy parent of Realtor.com for $950 million|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-murdochs-news-corp-in-950m-deal-to-buy-parent-of-realtorcom-20140930-story.html|accessdate=July 26, 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|date=September 30, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=News Corp to Buy Move Inc. for $950 Million|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/news-corp-to-buy-online-real-estate-business-move-inc-for-950-million-1412076494|accessdate=July 26, 2017|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=September 30, 2014|first1=Lukas I.|last1=Alpert|first2=Joe|last2=Light}}</ref> Ownership of Move is shared 80/20 between News Corp and [[REA Group]], respectively.<ref name=NYT/><ref name="Yu">{{cite news|last1=Yu|first1=Roger|title=News Corp. to buy Move Inc. for about $950M|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/09/30/news-corp-buys-move/16468211/|accessdate=July 26, 2017|work=USA Today|date=September 30, 2014}}</ref> The deal was endorsed by the National Association of Realtors, which licensed Move to operate the Realtor.com site.<ref name=Yu/> This agreement continued after the deal closed in November.<ref name=Completes/> In 2015, Move relocated its headquarters from [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] to Santa Clara.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Donato-Weinstein|first1=Nathan|title=Why News Corp.'s Move Inc. is leaving downtown San Jose for Santa Clara|journal=Silicon Valley Business Journal|date=July 21, 2015|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2015/07/21/why-news-corp-s-move-inc-is-leaving-downtown-san.html|accessdate=July 31, 2017}}</ref>
Move acquired the document and transaction management provider Reesio, which specializes in residential real estate, in October 2015. The financial terms were not disclosed, and Reesio's four founders joined Move's team.<ref name="Peters">{{cite web|last1=Peters|first1=Andy|title=News Corp's Move Acquires Online Home-Sales Platform Reesio|url=https://www.nationalmortgagenews.com/news/news-corps-move-acquires-online-home-sales-platform-reesio|website=National Mortgage News|accessdate=July 26, 2017}}</ref> In 2016, [[Zillow]] paid $130 million to Move and the National Association of Realtors to settle a lawsuit over trade secrets, following its employment of two individuals who had held executive roles at Move.<ref name=Collins/><ref name="Levy">{{cite web|last1=Levy|first1=Nat|title=Realtor.com's new features bring augmented reality, image recognition to home-buying|url=https://www.geekwire.com/2017/realtor-com-features-bring-augmented-reality-image-recognition-to-the-home-buying-process/|website=GeekWire|accessdate=July 7, 2017|date=January 17, 2017}}</ref> Move sold its lead-generation company TigerLeads to Commissions Inc., a [[customer relationship management]] system provider, in December.<ref name="TigerLeads">{{cite web|last1=Wiggin|first1=Teke|title=Realtor.com operator sells TigerLeads to Commissions Inc.: sources|url=https://www.inman.com/2016/12/02/realtor-com-operator-sells-tigerleads-to-confirm-buyer-commissions-inc/|website=Inman.com|accessdate=July 28, 2017|date=December 2, 2016}}</ref>
Move acquired Opcity, the Austin, Texas-based [[real estate technology]] company, for $210 million in 2018. The company, which developed a platform that uses artificial intelligence and machine learning to match potential home buyers with agents,<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.statesman.com/news/20180830/austin-real-estate-startup-opcity-to-be-acquired-for-210-million|title=Austin real estate startup Opcity to be acquired for $210 million|first=Lori|last=Hawkins|date=August 30, 2018|accessdate=October 10, 2018|work=Austin American-Statesman}}</ref> will continue to operate as an independent business.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Anderson |first1=Will |title=Opcity agrees to $210 million buyout by News Corp. |journal=Austin Business Journal |date=August 30, 2018 |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/news/2018/08/30/opcity-agrees-to-210-million-buyout-by-news-corp.html |accessdate=September 12, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Marinova |first1=Polina |title=Term Sheet -- Thursday, August 30 |journal=Fortune |date=August 30, 2018 |url=http://fortune.com/2018/08/30/term-sheet-thursday-august-30/ |accessdate=September 12, 2018}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox politician | name = Naim Qassem | nationality =[[Lebanese nationality law|Lebanese]] | image = Naim Kassim (01).jpg | caption = Naim Qassem in Beirut, 2009 | imagesize = | office = Deputy Secretary-General of Hezbollah | term_start = 1992 | term_end = | vicepresident = | predecessor = | successor = | birth_date ={{birth year and age|1953}} | birth_place =[[Kfar fila|Kfar Fila]], [[Lebanon]] | death_date = | death_place = |constituency = | party = [[Hezbollah]] | alma_meter =[[Lebanese University]] | religion = [[Twelver]] [[Shia Islam]] }} '''Naim Qassem''' ({{lang-ar|نعيم قاسم}}; born 1953) is a [[Shia Islam in Lebanon|Shia]] Lebanese cleric and politician, who is the second in command of [[Hezbollah]] with the title of deputy secretary-general.<ref>{{cite news|author=Andrew Coombes in Beirut|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2007/11/2008525183720231945.html|title=Interview: Naim Qassem|newspaper=Al Jazeera|year=2007|accessdate=31 January 2013}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Qassem was born into a [[Shia Islam in Lebanon|Shiite]] family in [[Kfar fila|Kfar Fila]] in 1953.<ref name=wmer5dec>{{cite news|title=Sayyed Nasrallah re-elected for another term|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Sayyed+Nasrallah+re-elected+for+another+term.-a0214528324|accessdate=24 March 2013|newspaper=The Weekly Middle East Reporter|date=5 December 2009}}</ref><ref name=AvonK2012>{{cite book|author1=Dominique Avon|author2=Anaïs-Trissa Khatchadourian|author3=Jane Marie Todd|title=Hezbollah: A History of the "Party of God"|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xOC6v4-XCHgC&pg=PA200|accessdate=14 April 2013|date=10 September 2012|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-06752-3|pages=210}}</ref> He studied theology and his teacher was [[Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah|Ayatollah Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah]].<ref name=wmer5dec/> He also received a bachelor's degree in chemistry from [[Lebanese University]].<ref name=wmer5dec/>
==Career== Qassem is one of the founders of Lebanese Muslim students union that was established in the 1970s.<ref name=AvonK2012/> He joined [[Amal Movement|the Amal movement]] when it was headed by [[Imam Musa Sadr]].<ref name=wmer5dec/> Qassem was the head of the Islamic religious education association from 1974 to 1988.<ref name=AvonK2012/> He also served as the advisor for al Mustafa schools.<ref name=AvonK2012/> Then Qassem participated in foundation activities of Hezbollah and was appointed deputy secretary-general of Hezbollah in 1992.<ref name=wmer5dec/><ref name=mer20nov>{{cite news|title=Hizbullah Renews Nasrallah as Head of Shiite Party; Forms A New Shura Council|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Lebanon-Hizbullah.-a0213406603|accessdate=24 March 2013|newspaper=The Daily Middle East Reporter|date=20 November 2009}}</ref>
==Works and views== In 2009, [[Mustafa Badr Al Din]] replaced [[Imad Mughniyah]] as the head of Hezbollah's military activities.<ref name=zvi25feb>{{cite news|last=Barel|first=Zvi|title=Who's breathing down Hezbollah leader's neck?|url=http://www.haaretz.com/opinion/who-s-breathing-down-hezbollah-leader-s-neck.premium-1.505676|accessdate=22 March 2013|newspaper=Haaretz|date=25 February 2013}}</ref> However, Qassem did not support it, favoring Samir Shehade.<ref name=zvi25feb/>
Qassem published a book, ''Hezbollah: The Story from Within'', in 2006.<ref name=glass17aug>{{cite journal|last=Glass|first=Charles|title=Learning from Its Mistakes: Charles Glass on Hizbullah|journal=London Review of Books|date=17 August 2006|url=http://www.charlesglass.net/archives/2006/08/learning_from_i_1.html|accessdate=9 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104201141/http://www.charlesglass.net/archives/2006/08/learning_from_i_1.html|archivedate=4 November 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 1 August 2011, Qassem attended a ceremony for the eighth edition of his book, where he made the statement that "Billions of dollars have been offered to us to rebuild the deprived south Lebanon and in return to surrender our arms and stop the work of the resistance. But we told them we're not in need [of their money] and the resistance will go on regardless of the consequences."<ref name=tds1aug>{{cite news|title=Hezbollah offered billions to disarm: Qassem|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/2011/Aug-01/Hezbollah-offered-billions-to-disarm-Qassem.ashx#axzz2ODDb0hpR|accessdate=24 March 2013|newspaper=The Daily Star|date=1 August 2011}}</ref>

{{no footnotes|date=January 2017}} '''Nedirbay Aytakov''' (1894 – October 28, 1938) was a Turkmenistani revolutionary and Soviet politician. He was born in Transcaspian Oblast. From May 21, 1925 to July 21, 1937, he served on the [[Central Executive Committee of the Soviet Union]] as a representative of the [[Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic]]. During the [[Great Purge]], he was executed by firing squad. After the death of [[Joseph Stalin]], he was rehabilitated.

'''North Korea Intellectuals Solidarity''' is a group of [[North Korea]]n [[dissident]]s resident in [[South Korea]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article7136011.ece|title=North Korea cuts all ties with South|date=May 26, 2010|author=Richard Lloyd Parry|publisher=The Times|accessdate=2011-06-10}}</ref>
It was founded by [[Kim Heung Kwang]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=127836840|title=Awareness Of Outside World Growing In North Korea|author=Mike Shuster|date=June 15, 2010|publisher=NPR|accessdate=2011-06-10}}</ref> in October 2008.
==Overview== NKIS’s mission is to promote freedom, democratization, reform, and human rights for North Korea. Its activities include:
*Conducting academic research on North Korea and unification *Researching ideas on the development and progression of North Korea *Cultivating the skills of North Korean defector intellectuals and fostering younger generations
The organization has also been known to smuggle in USB drives containing political information about South Korean governmental activities along with DVDs and other South Korean media content.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bower|first=Janine|title=What the Hallyu "Invasion" Means for North Korea|url=http://www.mtviggy.com/blog-posts/what-the-hallyu-%E2%80%9Cinvasion%E2%80%9D-means-for-north-korea/|publisher=[[MTV]] Iggy|accessdate=24 March 2013|quote=International organizations such as the North Korea Intellectuals Solidarity (NKIS) have been known to regularly smuggle in USB drives containing political information about South Korean governmental activities in the past, a practice that is now being mimicked with information carriers like USBs as well as DVDs with South Korean content on them, which are sold illegally after they cross the border.}}</ref>

{{For|the TV channel|One Australia (TV channel)}}{{For|the sunken racing yacht|OneAustralia|}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} '''''One Australia''''' was the [[Immigration to Australia|immigration]] and ethnic affairs [[policy]] of the [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]]-[[National Party of Australia|National]] [[Opposition (Australia)|Opposition]] in Australia, released in 1988. The One Australia policy proclaimed a vision of "one nation and one future". It called for an end to [[multiculturalism]] and opposed a treaty with [[Indigenous Australians|Aboriginal Australians]]. The policy set the scene for the August 1988 suggestion by [[List of Australian Leaders of the Opposition|Leader of the Opposition]] [[John Howard]] that the rate of Asian immigration to Australia be reduced. ==History== [[File:Howard2.JPG|thumbnail|[[John Howard]], Australian Prime Minister 1996–2007]] Howard first flagged the concept of the ''One Australia'' policy on a trip to [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] in July 1988, having recently returned from a visit with [[Margaret Thatcher]] in Britain. ''One Australia'' was to be the name of the Liberal-National [[Coalition (Australia)|Coalition's]] immigration and ethnic affairs policy.{{Cite book|last=Maddox |first=Marion |authorlink=Marion Maddox |title=God Under Howard: The Rise of the Religious Right in Australian Politics |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=or-BD19vOIAC&printsec=frontcover |accessdate=2008-03-03 |year=2005 |publisher=[[Allen & Unwin]] |isbn=1-74114-568-6 |pages=112–114 }} During an interview on the [[John Laws]] radio programme on 1 August 1988, Howard detailed the policy, expressing his preference to bias immigration towards skilled applicants rather than family reunion. {{Cite web | last1 = Jupp | first1 = James | authorlink = | author2 = John Warhurst and Marian Simms | title = Ethnicity and immigration | work = 2001: The Centenary Election | publisher = University of Queensland Press (UQP) | year = 2002 | url = http://www.api-network.com/main/index.php?apply=scholars&webpage=default&flexedit=&flex_password=&menu_label=&menuID=homely&menubox=&scholar=260 | archiveurl = http://www.api-network.com/main/pdf/scholars/aus8_jupp.pdf | archivedate = 2002 | accessdate = 2007-08-21}} Later that afternoon, on the [[PM (ABC Radio)|ABC PM]] programme, Howard discussed the policy in relation to Asian immigration to Australia:
I do believe that if it is – in the eyes of some in the community – that it's too great, it would be in our immediate-term interest and supporting of social cohesion if it were slowed down a little, so the capacity of the community to absorb it was greater.{{Cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/archive/news/asian-influence-spices-up-contest/news-story/97b8077825a4a8c15a9fa2127a6207e4|title=Asian influence spices up contest|last=|first=|date=27 February 2007|work=[[The Australian]]|access-date=10 December 2016|via=}}
Howard's Shadow Finance Minister, [[John Stone (Australian politician)|John Stone]], elaborated, saying that "Asian immigration has to be slowed. It's no use dancing around the bushes".{{Cite book | last =Peter | first =Mares | title =Borderline: Australia's Response to Refugees and Asylum Seekers in the Wake of the Tampa | publisher =UNSW Press | year =2002 | pages =113 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=XiPAMuTaQFEC&printsec=frontcover&dq=borderline | isbn =0-86840-789-5 }} [[Ian Sinclair]], National Party leader in the Coalition, also supported the policy, saying:
"What we are saying is that if there is any risk of an undue build-up of Asians as against others in the community, then you need to control it ... I certainly believe, that at the moment we need ... to reduce the number of Asians ... We don't want the divisions of South Africa, we don't want the divisions of London. We really don't want the colour divisions of the United States." {{cite book | last = Markus | first = Andrew | title = Race: John Howard and the Remaking of Australia | publisher = [[Allen & Unwin]] | year = 2001 | pages = 89 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=UA0-5v3JN0QC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=&f=false | isbn = 1-86448-866-2 }}
There were widespread objections to the policy from within the Liberal Party, including from [[Premier of Victoria|Victorian Premier]] [[Jeff Kennett]], [[Premier of New South Wales|New South Wales Premier]] [[Nick Greiner]], former Prime Minister [[Malcolm Fraser]], and former [[Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs|immigration ministers]] [[Ian Macphee]] and [[Michael MacKellar]]. The [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] government sought to quickly exploit Howard's Asian remarks by introducing a [[Parliament of Australia|parliamentary]] [[Motion (democracy)|motion]] rejecting the use of [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]] to select immigrants. Howard opposed this motion. {{Cite web | title = IMMIGRATION POLICY: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders | publisher = Parliament of Australia ([[Hansard]]) | date = 1988-08-25 | url = http://parlinfoweb.aph.gov.au/piweb//view_document.aspx?TABLE=HANSARDR&ID=440146 | accessdate = 2007-08-03 }} {{Cite news | last = Parkinson | first = Tony | title = Howard turns dissent into democracy | publisher = [[The Age]] | date = 2005-06-21 | url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/tony-parkinson/howard-turns-dissent-into-democracy/2005/06/20/1119250925679.html | accessdate = 2007-08-03 }} {{Cite web | last = Bob | first = Hawke | title = Speeches by The Hon RJL Hawke AC | publisher = [[University of South Australia|UniSA]] | date = 2001-05-08 | url = http://www.unisa.edu.au/hawkecentre/library/speeches/2001_may_alp.asp | accessdate = 2007-08-19 }} In an unusual show of [[dissent]], three Liberal [[Member of Parliament|MPs]]—[[Ian Macphee]], [[Steele Hall]] and [[Philip Ruddock]]—defied their leader by [[crossing the floor]] and voting with the Labor government. {{Cite news | last = Ramsey | first = Alan | title = The lost art of crossing the floor | publisher = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date = 2006-04-12 | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/opinion/the-lost-art-of-crossing-the-floor/2006/08/11/1154803093733.html | accessdate =2007-08-22}} Macphee lost preselection the following year.{{cite news |last=Hall |first=Bianca |date=23 February 2014 |title=Liberal Wets hang out principles on asylum-seeker policy to dry |url=http://www.watoday.com.au/comment/liberal-wets-hang-out-principles-on-asylumseeker-policy-to-dry-20140222-338ql.html |newspaper=WAtoday |location=Perth |publisher=Fairfax Media |deadurl=no |accessdate=2014-03-19}} Criticising his own party's policy, Steele Hall said in a speech to Parliament:
The question has quickly descended from a discussion about the future migrant intake to one about the level of internal racial tolerance. The simple fact is that public opinion is easily led on racial issues. It is now time to unite the community on the race issue before it flares into an ugly reproach for us all.
In a speech to the "Terra Australis to Australia" conference in [[Canberra]], August 1988, Prime Minister [[Bob Hawke]] responded to the Opposition's One Australia policy:
In the field of immigration and ethnic affairs, the "One Australia" ideology seems to connote a return to the dark days of narrow minded intolerance, fear of difference and pressure to assimilate. It is less about uniting Australians than dividing them. {{Cite web |url=http://docushare.unisa.edu.au/docushare/dsweb/Get/Document-4526/DAE165.pdf |title=Speech by the Prime Minister |accessdate=2007-12-12 |last=Hawke |first=Bob |authorlink=Bob Hawke |date=1988-08-21 |work=“Terra Australis to Australia” conference |publisher=[[University of South Australia|UniSA]] |pages=4–5}}
''One Australia'' was officially launched by John Howard on 22 August 1988. The policy document, whose title was personally chosen by Howard, stated the Coalition's ideal to create "One Australia and welcome all those who share our vision and are ready to contribute to it", detailing a vision of "one nation and one future" which included the rejection of [[Aboriginal land rights in Australia|Aboriginal land rights]]. In September 1988, John Howard criticised multiculturalism, saying "To me, multiculturalism suggests that we can't make up our minds who we are or what we believe in", and the idea of an Aboriginal treaty, saying "I abhor the notion of an Aboriginal treaty because it is repugnant to the ideals of One Australia".{{Cite book | last = Markus | first = Andrew | title = Race: John Howard and the Remaking of Australia | publisher = [[Allen & Unwin]] | year = 2001 | pages = 85–89 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=UA0-5v3JN0QC&pg=PP1&dq=%22race:+john+howard%22 | isbn = 1-86448-866-2 }} ''One Australia'' became the centrepiece of Howard's general policy manifesto, "Future Directions – It's Time for Plain Thinking", which was released in December 1988. In a January 1989 interview with [[Gerard Henderson]], Howard elaborated on his reasons for opposing multiculturalism:
The objection I have to multiculturalism is that multiculturalism is in effect saying that it is impossible to have an Australian ethos, that it is impossible to have a common Australian culture. So we have to pretend that we are a federation of cultures and that we've got a bit from every part of the world. I think that is hopeless.{{Cite news|title=Relaxed and comfortable |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/books/relaxed-and-comfortable/2005/09/08/1125772645170.html |publisher=''[[The Age]]'' |date=2005-09-10 |accessdate=2007-11-30 }}
In the months following the release of the One Australia policy, there was a decline in investment in Australia by Asian businesses. {{Cite book|last=Morris |first=Meaghan |title=Too Soon Too Late: History in Popular Culture |origyear=1998 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=71qdOHngcTAC&pg=RA1-PA306&vq=%22one+australia%22&dq=%22one+australia%22+howard |accessdate=2007-12-18 |publisher=Indiana University Press |isbn=0-253-33395-4 |pages=306–307 |year=1998 }} Some political commentators later postulated that the dissent within the Liberal Party over immigration policy weakened Howard's leadership position, contributing to him being overthrown as Liberal Party leader by [[Andrew Peacock]].{{Cite book|last=Kelly |first=Paul |authorlink=Paul Kelly (journalist) |title=The End of Certainty: Power, Politics, and Business in Australia |origyear=1994 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EKXBgmYeO2QC&dq |accessdate=2007-10-05 |publisher=[[Allen & Unwin]] |isbn=1-86373-757-X |pages=457 |year=1994 }} When Howard was in Government from 1996-2007 he increased immigration and increased multiculturalism. from migration rate of 30,042 in 1992–93 to 158,630 in 2007. ==Commentary on the One Australia policy== *In 1993, Liberal Party MP, [[Peter Costello]], dismissed the One Australia policy as just "a passing policy".{{Cite journal|last=Costello |first=Peter |authorlink=Peter Costello |date=September 1993 |title=The Liberal Party and its Future |journal=[[Australian Quarterly]] |volume=65 |issue=3 |pages=17 |url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/20635729?uid=3739256&uid=2&uid=4&sid=21103798593283 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2014-03-19 |doi=10.2307/20635729}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.jcu.edu.au/aff/history/articles/brawley.htm |title=A Comfortable and Relaxed Past': John Howard and the 'Battle of History' |accessdate=2007-12-09 |last=Brawley |first=Sean |date=2007-04-27 |work=The Electronic Journal of Australian and New Zealand History |publisher=[[James Cook University]] }} *In a 2007 article in the British newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]'', [[Left-wing politics|left wing]] journalist [[John Pilger]] claimed that the One Australia Policy was a forerunner to the [[One Nation (Australia)|One Nation]] political party.{{Cite news|title=Cruelty and xenophobia stir and shame the lucky country |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/story/0,,1994045,00.html |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=2007-01-19 |accessdate=2007-12-10 | location=London | first=John | last=Pilger}} ==See also== * [[Criticism of multiculturalism]] * [[Opposition to immigration]] * [[White Australia policy]] ==References==
